[{'created': '2019-08-07 08:09:36.000000000', 'message': 'Enable iscsid on cinder-backup hosts

Without this we may see the following error in cinder-backup when using
the LVM backend:

    Could not login to any iSCSI portal

Enabling the iscsid container on hosts in the cinder-backup group fixes
this.

Closes-Bug: #1838624

Change-Id: If373c002b0744ce9dbdffed50a02bab55dd0acb9
Co-Authored-By: dmitry-a-grachev <dmitry.a.grachev@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Enable iscsid on cinder-backup hosts

Without this we may see the following error in cinder-backup when using
the LVM backend:

    Could not login to any iSCSI portal

Enabling the iscsid container on hosts in the cinder-backup group fixes
this.

Closes-Bug: #1838624

Change-Id: If373c002b0744ce9dbdffed50a02bab55dd0acb9
Co-Authored-By: dmitry-a-grachev <dmitry.a.grachev@gmail.com>

subject: [gnocchi] Don't recursively modify file perms on start
messages:
[{'account_id': 29100, 'date': '2019-07-18 22:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 16006, 'date': '2019-07-19 14:53:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-07-23 05:48:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Is it empty on initial deploy? What's in there?"}, {'account_id': 29100, 'date': '2019-07-23 20:59:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Is it empty on initial deploy? What's in there?

The config.json instructs what should happen on each restart. On every restart, no matter if it's the initial deploy or a later run, it will attempt to chown the entire directory recursively via a nested Python loop. So after you have a substantial amount of Gnocchi data, this becomes untenable."}, {'account_id': 29100, 'date': '2019-07-23 21:02:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I should also say that yes, it is empty on initial deploy. This recursive chown was added in response to this bug with upgrades: https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla/+bug/1631503. In that case, I think the problem should be fixed as part of the kolla_extend_start script for Gnocchi as opposed to here (or perhaps explicitly in kolla-ansible as a different process.)'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-07-24 05:17:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Thanks for the background. Yeah, it seems more like a workaround than proper fix. We should just have proper permissions in images and handle any differences in upgrades. That said, the change you mentioned is from 2016. The code has changed quite a bit since then and so has the perspective I believe. The real problem should be handled globally.'}, {'account_id': 28614, 'date': '2019-07-25 14:52:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 22629, 'date': '2019-08-05 07:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-08-05 16:59:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I expect there are a few other places where this change could be applied.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-08-06 06:51:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I expect there are a few other places where this change could be
 > applied.

Probably, added a bug for that: https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1839059 so that we don't forget (at least not too quickly)."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-08-15 08:20:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/stein as commit 5af3a56906cdfd1467d29b001ae95af8524220ae'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-08-15 08:20:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/rocky as commit 5e83ba5bbec8cc9c2dbef1983e538cf2599dd67b'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-18 22:19:07.000000000', 'message': "[gnocchi] Don't recursively modify file perms on start

For deployments with a lot of Gnocchi data, this is a non-starter
(literally... the service basically can't start.) There maybe needs to
be a way to configure this, or only do it during deploy/bootstrap?
Unclear, but disabling for now; users can `chown -R gnocchi:gnocchi`
themselves in the meantime if need be.

Change-Id: I0bae6dfbbee9f63506c89bd6b392e7be07fd5930
"}]
commit_message:
[gnocchi] Don't recursively modify file perms on start

For deployments with a lot of Gnocchi data, this is a non-starter
(literally... the service basically can't start.) There maybe needs to
be a way to configure this, or only do it during deploy/bootstrap?
Unclear, but disabling for now; users can `chown -R gnocchi:gnocchi`
themselves in the meantime if need be.

Change-Id: I0bae6dfbbee9f63506c89bd6b392e7be07fd5930

subject: Use hiera interpolation for ceph monitor_address_block
messages:
[{'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-08-13 12:34:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-08-13 12:35:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Will remove -W once the patch has been tested.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-08-15 08:19:16.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Proposing a fix in ceph-ansible instead, see: https://github.com/ceph/ceph-ansible/pull/4339'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-13 12:34:39.000000000', 'message': "Use hiera interpolation for ceph monitor_address_block

When deploying with multiple subnets on the CephMonNetwork
the CIDR for all subnets where passed to ceph-ansible's
monitor_address_block parameter. ceph-ansible does not
support a list of CIDR's for this parameter.

By using hiera interpolation we pass only the subnet CIDR
that is valid for the current node.

Closes-Bug: #1840030
Change-Id: Ia73fc82f358269047d28b67741e35debe400c107
"}]
commit_message:
Use hiera interpolation for ceph monitor_address_block

When deploying with multiple subnets on the CephMonNetwork
the CIDR for all subnets where passed to ceph-ansible's
monitor_address_block parameter. ceph-ansible does not
support a list of CIDR's for this parameter.

By using hiera interpolation we pass only the subnet CIDR
that is valid for the current node.

Closes-Bug: #1840030
Change-Id: Ia73fc82f358269047d28b67741e35debe400c107

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-28 13:49:37.000000000', 'message': 'Handle more return codes from nova-status upgrade check

Currently, the "Upgrade status check result" does nothing because the
previous task can only succeed when `nova-status upgrade check` returns
code 0. This change allows this command to err so that the value of
returned code stored in `nova_upgrade_check_stdout` can then be
analysed.

This change also allows for warnings (rc 1) to pass.

Change-Id: I6f5e37832f43f23604920b9d890cc505ca924ff9
'}, {'created': '2019-06-28 13:54:12.000000000', 'message': 'Handle more return codes from nova-status upgrade check

Currently, the "Upgrade status check result" does nothing because the
previous task can only succeed when `nova-status upgrade check` returns
code 0. This change allows this command to err so that the value of
returned code stored in `nova_upgrade_check_stdout` can then be
analysed.

This change also allows for warnings (rc 1) to pass.
Closes-Bug: 1834647

Change-Id: I6f5e37832f43f23604920b9d890cc505ca924ff9

commit_message:
Handle more return codes from nova-status upgrade check

In a single controller scenario, the "Upgrade status check result"
does nothing because the previous task can only succeed when
`nova-status upgrade check` returns code 0. This change allows this
command to fail, so that the value of returned code stored in
`nova_upgrade_check_stdout` can then be analysed.

This change also allows for warnings (rc 1) to pass.
Closes-Bug: 1834647

Change-Id: I6f5e37832f43f23604920b9d890cc505ca924ff9

commit_message:
Fix the redis_connection_string for osprofiler and make it generic

* When using redis as the backend of osprofiler, it cannot connect to
redis because the redis_connection_string is incorrect.

* Let other places that use redis also use this variable.

Change-Id: I14de6597932d05cd7f804a35c6764ba4ae9087cd
Closes-Bug: #1833200
Signed-off-by: ZijianGuo <guozijn@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Fix checking mongodb replication status

backport: stein, rocky

The reason it did not work before was that the other handlers had never been called
after [0], tasks from start.yml were move to handler which cannot act
like tasks, also bootstrap tasks must run after 'Restart mongodb container'.

This commit adds a notify after 'Restart mongodb container' for triger
task 'bootstrap_cluster.yml'.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/40b635b9c538e3d971f6e40db4fb3900135117e6

Change-Id: I4e2fbe9a8f20afcc4e25a01e23e5231e74eeeec4

commit_message:
Ensures monasca-thresh data and worker dirs exist and are empty on start up

This prevents the filesystem from filling up with Apache Storm
temporary files which will otherwise not be cleared.

Change-Id: Ib07e32f4e67e500f10986103d781dfd3874ffdd2
Partial-Bug: #1839149

commit_message:
Add `filename` parameter to Redfish virtual media boot URL

Some BMCs seem to validate virtual media boot image URL requiring
that URL to end with something resembling ISO image file name
(perhaps, its suffix i.e. extension).

This patch tries to add, hopefully, meaningless `filename`
parameter to boot URL's query string in hope to make the entire boot
image URL looking more convincing to the BMC.

Change-Id: I316712b38d10c0e801f7fd96a584074c8918b46b
Story: 1526753
Task: 10389

commit_message:
Delete default gnocchi & aodh wsgi conf in Ubuntu binary

Ubuntu distro package will create default wsgi conf in apache
during gnocchi-api and aodh-api installation. We need to delete
them since we only use the conf that pushed by kolla-ansible.

Change-Id: Ib31e733eba12deebdf469c306dfba4191a1b89f5
Related-Bug: 1832306
Related-Bug: 1836520

subject: Add network config to stabilise multi-NIC scenario
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6484, 'name': 'Feilong Wang', 'email': 'hustemb@gmail.com', 'username': 'flwang'}, {'_account_id': 7822, 'name': 'Chris Hoge (not involved in upstream development)', 'email': 'chris@hogepodge.com', 'username': 'hogepodge'}, {'_account_id': 8064, 'name': 'Jake Yip', 'email': 'jake.yip@unimelb.edu.au', 'username': 'jake'}, {'_account_id': 20498, 'name': 'Spyros Trigazis', 'email': 'strigazi@gmail.com', 'username': 'strigazi'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 28022, 'name': 'Bharat Kunwar', 'email': 'brtknr@bath.edu', 'username': 'brtknr'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-06-20 16:09:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-06-20 16:12:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2019-07-25 17:34:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I'm not sure this is the correct way to solve this problem. The cloud-config file is generated by Magnum for the particular cloud, so appending the new value to a new file circumvents the creation and adds an extra step. We should be adding the parameter at config generation time, rather than creating a new file and modifying the configuration."}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-07-26 11:28:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I'm not sure this is the correct way to solve this problem. The
 > cloud-config file is generated by Magnum for the particular cloud,
 > so appending the new value to a new file circumvents the creation
 > and adds an extra step. We should be adding the parameter at config
 > generation time, rather than creating a new file and modifying the
 > configuration.

Hi Chris,

Thanks for your review. Like you, I would also prefer a single configuration file. However, the OCCM supports config options which in-tree Cinder volume provider rejects, which is why we have 2 files with slightly different config. Once we start using out-of-tree Cinder volumes, this changes can be partially reverted.

Best

Bharat"}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-07-26 12:42:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-07-26 12:43:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I'm not sure this is the correct way to solve this problem. The
 > cloud-config file is generated by Magnum for the particular cloud,
 > so appending the new value to a new file circumvents the creation
 > and adds an extra step. We should be adding the parameter at config
 > generation time, rather than creating a new file and modifying the
 > configuration.

I have made a minor tweak which avoids copying and appending to file."}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-07-26 12:44:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-07-28 21:49:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-07-29 09:05:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-07-29 09:06:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> (1 comment)

Oops sorry I missed the `-occm` when I refactored the code.'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-07-29 09:07:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2019-07-29 20:25:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

Thanks for clarifying that Bharat.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-07-29 23:38:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

LGTM, thanks.'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2019-08-01 09:32:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-20 16:09:45.000000000', 'message': 'Specify internal network to improve stability in a multi-NIC scenario.

When there is more than one NIC attached to an instance, openstack cloud
provider returns a random InternalIP back to the host resulting in instability
with API server which only talks to a default interface.

This patch incorporates the changes made in
https://github.com/kubernetes/cloud-provider-openstack/pull/444 which enables
OpenStack Cloud Controller Manager (OCCM) to respect the
`internal-network-name` in cloud-config file which ensures that InternalIP
remains stable.

Uses a separate cloud-config file for OCCM to ensure in-tree Cinder volumes
remain compatible.

Change-Id: Idfa52ed2d512e7dc383a556371e896205dd542f9
Story: 2005333
Task: 30271

commit_message:
Add network config to stabilise multi-NIC scenario

When there is more than one NIC attached to an instance, openstack cloud
provider returns a random InternalIP back to the host resulting in instability
with API server which only talks to a default interface.

This patch incorporates the changes made in
https://github.com/kubernetes/cloud-provider-openstack/pull/444 which enables
OpenStack Cloud Controller Manager (OCCM) to respect the
`internal-network-name` in cloud-config file which ensures that InternalIP
remains stable.

Uses a separate cloud-config file for OCCM to ensure in-tree Cinder volumes
remain compatible.

Change-Id: Idfa52ed2d512e7dc383a556371e896205dd542f9
Story: 2005333
Task: 30271

Failure looks real. I assume something has changed with the logging library in Python 3.7. Can you investigate?'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-07-05 18:57:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't have cycles to fix unfortunately. It's up to the teams to fix per the TC goal. I'm just submitting patches for all the projects."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-07-19 21:36:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I tried investigating this but didn't get to the bottom of it. The symptoms would be explained by the log level still being set to something higher than INFO, but that doesn't seem to be the cause.

The code in _load_log_config() resets the level of all of the loggers (including the root logger - which seems possibly wrong) to NOTSET. However, even explicitly setting the levels to DEBUG here (and confirming that it is set in the test - so this code is definitely running, and nothing else overrides it) does not help. I'm forced to conclude that the issue is something other than the level of the logger, but I don't know what that could be."}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-08-14 15:46:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Stephen, are you ok with the code? If so would you be able to remove your CR-1? The tests will gate this from being merged, assuming you are ok with the code.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-08-14 16:12:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-08-14 16:12:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

[{'created': '2019-08-14 16:30:42.000000000', 'message': 'Retry Elasticsearch synced flush during upgrade

The synced flush can fail with a HTTP 409 Conflict if indexing operations are
occurring concurrently. Retry the operation until success or a number of

'}]
commit_message:
Retry Elasticsearch synced flush during upgrade

The synced flush can fail with a HTTP 409 Conflict if indexing operations are
occurring concurrently. Retry the operation until success or a number of
attempts have been reached (default 12 - 120 seconds).

Change-Id: Id7809f7d0d016e7f7c1987f806963b985fa89830

I opened another bug to see if we can get this fixed at the source: https://bugs.python.org/issue37857'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2019-08-15 05:20:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9796, 'date': '2019-08-15 05:44:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-14 16:08:50.000000000', 'message': 'Use setLevel instead of setting logger.level directly

Python 3.7 added caching of the log level for calls to isEnabledFor
on a logger[0]. As a result, modifying the logger level directly
can cause a mismatch in behavior if a log call was made prior to
that modification. In our case, we were calling logger.info before
the info level was enabled, which meant the logger cached the fact
that it was not enabled for info-level logging. Even after setting
the level to NOTSET, it was still remembering that it shouldn't log
info messages and that breaks our unit tests on py37. There is a
related issue open against Python[1], but basically the answer there
was "don't mess with logger internals".

The simple fix is to use logger.setLevel for resetting the log level
instead of modifying the attribute directly.

Change-Id: Ifd1300d8e4280df1913f632e964f9458dbb2db55
0: https://github.com/python/cpython/commit/78c18a9b9a1445f7c755929917a790ba02b4a5e0#diff-5bd69232a06838f179312d3e48ccf506
1: https://bugs.python.org/issue34269
Closes-Bug: 1783630
'}]
commit_message:
Use setLevel instead of setting logger.level directly

Python 3.7 added caching of the log level for calls to isEnabledFor
on a logger[0]. As a result, modifying the logger level directly
can cause a mismatch in behavior if a log call was made prior to
that modification. In our case, we were calling logger.info before
the info level was enabled, which meant the logger cached the fact
that it was not enabled for info-level logging. Even after setting
the level to NOTSET, it was still remembering that it shouldn't log
info messages and that breaks our unit tests on py37. There is a
related issue open against Python[1], but basically the answer there
was "don't mess with logger internals".

The simple fix is to use logger.setLevel for resetting the log level
instead of modifying the attribute directly.

Change-Id: Ifd1300d8e4280df1913f632e964f9458dbb2db55
0: https://github.com/python/cpython/commit/78c18a9b9a1445f7c755929917a790ba02b4a5e0#diff-5bd69232a06838f179312d3e48ccf506
1: https://bugs.python.org/issue34269
Closes-Bug: 1783630

commit_message:
Also assign default subnets to network segment

Right now only additional subnets get assigned to a network segment.
But this fails as either all or none subnets on a network must be
assigned with segments.

This removes the conditional to also assign the default subnet to
the segment.

Change-Id: Ief7af583d03c07f30662abf86da21451f8361197
Closes-Bug: #1840039

commit_message:
Refactor variables in plugin.sh to simplify setting a datastore

Remove several variables local to plugin.sh so it is possible to
set a non default datastore by changing only the 3 most obvious ones:

TROVE_DATASTORE_TYPE
TROVE_DATASTORE_VERSION
TROVE_DATASTORE_PACKAGE

Change-Id: I782757647985bdfb859043fe68e2b4cd27569ab3

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-17 17:10:41.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Add CrossCellMigrationTask

This adds the main conductor task that will orchestrate
a cross-cell resize. This will get called from the
existing conductor MigrationTask when that task determines
the scheduler picked a target host in another cell for the
resize operation.

The only thing CrossCellMigrationTask does in this change
is run the TargetDBSetupTask sub-task.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: I4d181b44494f3b0b04537d5798537831c8fdf400

'}, {'created': '2019-01-30 00:51:17.000000000', 'message': 'Add CrossCellMigrationTask

This adds the main conductor task that will orchestrate
a cross-cell resize. This will get called from the
existing conductor MigrationTask when that task determines
the scheduler picked a target host in another cell for the
resize operation.

The only thing CrossCellMigrationTask does in this change
is perform checks on the neutron and cinder APIs to make
sure they are new enough for what we need before we go any
further with the resize.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

resize operation.

The only thing CrossCellMigrationTask does in this change
is perform checks on the neutron and cinder APIs to make
sure they are new enough for what we need before we go any
further with the resize.

commit_message:
Add CrossCellMigrationTask

This adds the main conductor task that will orchestrate
a cross-cell resize. This will get called from the
existing conductor MigrationTask when that task determines
the scheduler picked a target host in another cell for the
resize operation.

The only thing CrossCellMigrationTask does in this change
is perform checks on the neutron and cinder APIs to make
sure they are new enough for what we need before we go any
further with the resize.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: I4d181b44494f3b0b04537d5798537831c8fdf400

[{'created': '2019-07-10 20:26:06.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Initial support for tls_priorities

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/670155
Change-Id: I703b5a429f48063474aace85bc45d948f5c91435
'}, {'created': '2019-07-11 06:48:50.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Initial support for tls_priorities

Depends-On: I1971810f6a90f244ed5ced972a5fe7fde29dde86
Change-Id: I703b5a429f48063474aace85bc45d948f5c91435
'}, {'created': '2019-07-17 17:42:45.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Initial support for tls_priorities

We add initial support for being able to specify tls priorities in
pacemaker. For bundles this will happen via an env variable because
pacemaker_remote is started normally as a process and there is no
sourcing of /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker.

WIP as I want to test this review fully on stein too (a partial version
of this patch was already tested on queens)

Depends-On: I1971810f6a90f244ed5ced972a5fe7fde29dde86
Change-Id: I703b5a429f48063474aace85bc45d948f5c91435
'}, {'created': '2019-07-22 15:46:52.000000000', 'message': 'Initial support for tls_priorities

We add initial support for being able to specify tls priorities in
pacemaker. For bundles this will happen via an env variable because
pacemaker_remote is started normally as a process and there is no
sourcing of /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker.

Tested on both queens and stein. Via a deploy and a redeploy against
existing cloud. Observed that:
A) We got PCMK_tls_priorities inside /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker with the
value that was passed in THT
B) Containers had the following env variable set:
  "PCMK_tls_priorities=normal",

Depends-On: I1971810f6a90f244ed5ced972a5fe7fde29dde86
Change-Id: I703b5a429f48063474aace85bc45d948f5c91435
'}, {'created': '2019-07-22 15:48:47.000000000', 'message': 'Initial support for tls_priorities

We add initial support for being able to specify tls priorities in
pacemaker. For bundles this will happen via an env variable because
pacemaker_remote is started normally as a process and there is no
sourcing of /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker.

Tested on both queens and stein. Via a deploy and a redeploy against
existing cloud. Observed that:
A) We got PCMK_tls_priorities inside /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker with the
value that was passed in THT
B) Containers had the following env variable set:
  "PCMK_tls_priorities=normal",

The '-e' addition is a noop in case the PCMK_tls_priorities is unset
so that we do not change the signature of the resources and hence do
not needlessly restart the HA resource.

Depends-On: I1971810f6a90f244ed5ced972a5fe7fde29dde86
Change-Id: I703b5a429f48063474aace85bc45d948f5c91435
'}, {'created': '2019-07-24 05:29:19.000000000', 'message': 'Initial support for tls_priorities

We add initial support for being able to specify tls priorities in
pacemaker. For bundles this will happen via an env variable because

commit_message:
Initial support for tls_priorities

We add initial support for being able to specify tls priorities in
pacemaker. For bundles this will happen via an env variable because
pacemaker_remote is started normally as a process and there is no
sourcing of /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker.

Tested on both queens and stein. Via a deploy and a redeploy against
existing cloud. Observed that:
A) We got PCMK_tls_priorities inside /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker with the
value that was passed in THT
B) Containers had the following env variable set:
  "PCMK_tls_priorities=normal",

The '-e' addition is a noop in case the PCMK_tls_priorities is unset
so that we do not change the signature of the resources and hence do
not needlessly restart the HA resource.

Depends-On: I1971810f6a90f244ed5ced972a5fe7fde29dde86
Change-Id: I703b5a429f48063474aace85bc45d948f5c91435

subject: Add set_boot_device hook in `redfish` boot interface

commit_message:
Add set_boot_device hook in `redfish` boot interface

Added `_set_boot_device()` method to `redfish` boot interface to
let future fishy hardware types reusing standard `redfish`
implementation modulo setting boot device procedure.

With Redfish, it seems, setting node to boot from Cd implies booting
from either virtual or physical CD depending on media presence in
either of the devices.

Change-Id: I576b90be46f9cadf1a051e17c95a98aefc83fe1f

commit_message:
Start enforcing E125 flake8 directive

Removed E125 (continuation line does not distinguish itself
from next logical line) from the ignore list and fixed all
the indentation issues.  Recently done in neutron tree.

Change-Id: Id002c874af7197823df4577035803528296dd4b7

commit_message:
tripleo-ci-fedora-28-standalone job is deprecated

tripleo-ci-fedora-28-standalone is deprecated and should be
disabled in all tripleo repos.

Task: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/1229

(5 comments)

Might be this has been discussed, and voted down earlier. But looks like a lot of this could be shared by multiple drivers?'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-02-22 06:17:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Might be this has been discussed, and voted down earlier. But looks like a lot of this could be shared by multiple drivers?

I've not tried that yet for two reasons:

* While the workflow is indeed similar, there are still tiny little vendor-specific weirdness here and there
* I see that code sharing between `irmc` and `ilo` is quite modest

So my feeling is that it is indeed feasible to cut out the common things, but the more we generalize the harder it might be to read the code...

My other though in that regard is that may be we should better figure out redfish boot interface first, then attempt to rebase ilo & irmc bits on the stable foundation...?"}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-02-25 00:04:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > Might be this has been discussed, and voted down earlier. But
 > looks like a lot of this could be shared by multiple drivers?
 > 
 > I've not tried that yet for two reasons:
 > 
 > * While the workflow is indeed similar, there are still tiny little
 > vendor-specific weirdness here and there
 >

Yeah, I may be overly optimistic about how standardized things are.

 > * I see that code sharing between `irmc` and `ilo` is quite modest
 > 

I guess my worry is that these drivers where developed by independent vendor teams that may not prioritize making the code sharable between implementations. (I realize I'm prejudicing, it may not be straight forward.)

 > So my feeling is that it is indeed feasible to cut out the common
 > things, but the more we generalize the harder it might be to read
 > the code...
 > 
 > My other though in that regard is that may be we should better
 > figure out redfish boot interface first, then attempt to rebase ilo
 > & irmc bits on the stable foundation...?

Sounds like a good plan!"}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-03-25 17:59:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 30100, 'date': '2019-03-25 18:34:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Ilya: I have tested this patch on ProLiant Gen10 server for partition image with boot option as 'local' and 'netboot'. It works fine except for the need of passing 'write_protected' argument during virtual media insertion.

(1 comment)

> @Shivanand I've added bits to set boot mode, I think we missed that
 > although it's kind of implicit with virtual media boot. Still, my
 > testing with Dell reveal that boot mode needs to be set explicitly.
 > WDYT?

You should not be needing to set the boot mode. Your machine might have been in Legacy BIOS mode or UEFI was not fully applied. Moreover, we should not call sync_boot_mode, as that method can set set boot mode even to LEGACY as it decides based on the multiple conditions. Can you retry by setting the boot mode manually to UEFI. Better to document that system needs to be in UEFI boot mode for using this interface."}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-07-19 11:10:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 38:

> You should not be needing to set the boot mode. Your machine might have been in Legacy BIOS mode or UEFI was not fully applied.

My understanding is that `sync_boot_mode` would (for properly configured ironic node) set bare metal nodal to UEFI, which is the requirement to be documented, no?

> Moreover, we should not call sync_boot_mode, as that method can set set boot mode even to LEGACY as it decides based on the multiple conditions.

I am not sure I understand how that could happen if ironic node is properly configured to boot UEFI...?

? Can you retry by setting the boot mode manually to UEFI.

Do you mean calling `set_boot_mode('uefi')` right from redfish boot interface? I though about that, but it sort of ignores ironic node configuration what seems a bit inconsistent to me from user perspective. Why do we have many ways to switch baremetal node to UEFI, but ignore that in the end? ;-)
 
> Better to document that system needs to be in UEFI boot mode for using this interface.

Oh, absolutely! I plan on working on the doc once it's all settled technically."}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-07-19 11:17:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 38:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-07-22 12:09:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 38:

@Shivanand Hey, I am looking for your insight!

When I was coding this patch, I somehow came to conclusion that booting from virtual media implies booting in UEFI mode. So I believed in that firmly till someone questioned my belief. I tried to recall why I though so, but I can't find anything supporting my initial belief anymore. %-)

So my question is - does (Redfish) virtual media boot imply UEFI boot mode, or not necessarily? WDYT?

Also, how does it work with HPE machines?

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2019-07-22 12:29:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 38:

> @Shivanand Hey, I am looking for your insight!
 > 
 > When I was coding this patch, I somehow came to conclusion that
 > booting from virtual media implies booting in UEFI mode. So I
 > believed in that firmly till someone questioned my belief. I tried
 > to recall why I though so, but I can't find anything supporting my
 > initial belief anymore. %-)
 > 
 > So my question is - does (Redfish) virtual media boot imply UEFI
 > boot mode, or not necessarily? WDYT?
 > 
 > Also, how does it work with HPE machines?
 > 
 > Thanks!
The booting from virtual media has nothing to do with the UEFI boot mode. It an work in both BIOS and UEFI.

 > @Shivanand Hey, I am looking for your insight!
 > 
 > When I was coding this patch, I somehow came to conclusion that
 > booting from virtual media implies booting in UEFI mode. So I
 > believed in that firmly till someone questioned my belief. I tried
 > to recall why I though so, but I can't find anything supporting my
 > initial belief anymore. %-)
 > 
 > So my question is - does (Redfish) virtual media boot imply UEFI
 > boot mode, or not necessarily? WDYT?
 > 
 > Also, how does it work with HPE machines?
 > 
 > Thanks!
@Ilya: Virtual media boot can happen in both UEFI and Legacy BIOS boot mode. But given that 'Legacy BIOS' boot mode will go out of support shortly, it was decide to support this boot interface with UEFI boot mode only. See comment from Julia  https://review.opendev.org/#/c/638453/29/ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/boot.py at L41."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-07-22 14:22:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 38: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

LGTM, Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-07-22 16:41:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 38:

> Virtual media boot can happen in both UEFI and Legacy BIOS boot mode. But given that 'Legacy BIOS' boot mode will go out of support shortly, it was decide to support this boot interface with UEFI boot mode only.

In that case, may be we should not deprive the user from booting in good-old-rusty BIOS way? Current design is based on my (hopefully, incorrect) understanding of UEFI requirement. If we leave UEFI as a must in this patch, we would effectively diverge from the standard.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2019-07-23 06:33:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 38:

> > Virtual media boot can happen in both UEFI and Legacy BIOS boot
 > mode. But given that 'Legacy BIOS' boot mode will go out of support
 > shortly, it was decide to support this boot interface with UEFI
 > boot mode only.
 > 
 > In that case, may be we should not deprive the user from booting in
 > good-old-rusty BIOS way? Current design is based on my (hopefully,
 > incorrect) understanding of UEFI requirement. If we leave UEFI as a
 > must in this patch, we would effectively diverge from the standard.
 > 
 > Thoughts?

I think, if required, we can add that support later."}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-07-23 06:44:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 38:

Alright, I will do a follow up then.'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-07-23 10:32:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 38:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-21 16:22:19.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Add Redfish Virtual Media support

This is the first in the series of patches introducing
standard Redfish virtual media support to ironic.

The first patch implements just minimalistic redfish
boot interface supporting just deploy and instance
image boot.

The upcoming patches will add unit tests, rescue and
possibly user ISO image booting.

Next steps should address DHCP-less booting, boot
from volume, possibly boot over iSCSI and NFS.

The other challenge is that we currently have neither
Redfish BMC nor virtual media emulation to test ironic
against. May be having an emulator would be an option
for the time being...

Story: 1526753
Task: 10389
Change-Id: I0db0a64c5ccf260f5a0695dbe994af1e11f71517

This is the first in the series of patches introducing
standard Redfish virtual media support to ironic.

This patch implements basic boot interface features along with
devstack plugin support for virtual media boot. Functionally,
redfish boot interface supports the same set of features as PXE.

Unlike other virtual media boot implementations (e.g. iLo), this
patch does not require user-built deploy/rescue/boot ISO images
for virtual media boot. Instead, ironic will build necessary images
out of common kernel/ramdisk pair (though user needs to provide
ESP image).

commit_message:
Add Redfish Virtual Media Boot support

This patch introduces standard Redfish virtual media boot
support to ironic.

The patch implements basic boot interface features along with
devstack plugin support for virtual media boot. Functionally,
redfish boot interface supports the same set of features as PXE.

Unlike other virtual media boot implementations (e.g. iLo), this
patch does not require user-built deploy/rescue/boot ISO images
for virtual media boot. Instead, ironic will build necessary images
out of common kernel/ramdisk pair (though user needs to provide
ESP image).

Story: 1526753
Task: 10389
Co-Authored-By: Shivanand Tendulker <stendulker@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I0db0a64c5ccf260f5a0695dbe994af1e11f71517

commit_message:
Switch TaskFlow engine to parallel

The default TaskFlow engine is now set to 'parallel' instead of
'serial'. The parallel engine schedules tasks onto different threads to
allow for running non-dependent tasks simultaneously. This has the
benefit of accelerating the execution of some Octavia Amphora flows such
as provisioning of active-standby amphora loadbalancers.

commit_message:
api-ref: Fix collapse of 'host_status' description

Fix collapse of 'host_status' description in the follwoing APIs
in the compute API reference.

- PUT /servers/{server_id}
- POST /servers/{server_id}/action (rebuild)

Change-Id: I003f9a81ac6f7e0ec13a24db3fda1b7ff6612bc5
Closes-Bug: #1840094

commit_message:
RAID creation fails with 'ilo5' RAID interface

RAID interface methods do not clear driver_internal_info properly
leads to failure of RAID operation when they are attempted again.

Change-Id: I3cd133fb700ec4946471d9e4cbebeab4bded4540
Story: 2006321
Task: 36052
(cherry picked from commit 6305ea70077f031f5033e7bb33b9321178f0c413)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-12 12:06:16.000000000', 'message': 'Populate binding levels when concurrent ops fail

Concurrent calls to _bind_port_if_needed may lead to a missing RPC
notification which can cause a port stuck in a DOWN state. If the only
caller that succeeds in the concurrency does not specify that an RPC
notification is allowed then no RPC would be sent to the agent. The
other caller which needs to send an RPC notification will fail since the
resulting PortContext instance will not have any binding levels set.

The failure has negative effects on consumers of the L2Population
functionality because the L2Population mechanism driver will not be
triggered to publish that a port is UP on a given compute node. Manual
intervention is required in this case.

This patch proposes to handle this by populating the PortContext with
the current binding levels so that the caller can continue on and have
an RPC notification sent out.

Closes-Bug: #1755810
Story: 2003922
Change-Id: Ie2b813b2bdf181fb3c24743dbd13487ace6ee76a
(cherry picked from commit 0dc730c7c0d3f0a49dee28d0d6e7ff9020d94443)
'}, {'created': '2019-08-13 07:38:07.000000000', 'message': 'Populate binding levels when concurrent ops fail

Concurrent calls to _bind_port_if_needed may lead to a missing RPC
notification which can cause a port stuck in a DOWN state. If the only
caller that succeeds in the concurrency does not specify that an RPC
notification is allowed then no RPC would be sent to the agent. The
other caller which needs to send an RPC notification will fail since the
resulting PortContext instance will not have any binding levels set.

The failure has negative effects on consumers of the L2Population
functionality because the L2Population mechanism driver will not be
triggered to publish that a port is UP on a given compute node. Manual
intervention is required in this case.

This patch proposes to handle this by populating the PortContext with
the current binding levels so that the caller can continue on and have
an RPC notification sent out.

Closes-Bug: #1755810
Story: 2003922
Change-Id: Ie2b813b2bdf181fb3c24743dbd13487ace6ee76a
(cherry picked from commit 0dc730c7c0d3f0a49dee28d0d6e7ff9020d94443)
'}]
commit_message:
Populate binding levels when concurrent ops fail

Concurrent calls to _bind_port_if_needed may lead to a missing RPC
notification which can cause a port stuck in a DOWN state. If the only
caller that succeeds in the concurrency does not specify that an RPC
notification is allowed then no RPC would be sent to the agent. The
other caller which needs to send an RPC notification will fail since the
resulting PortContext instance will not have any binding levels set.

The failure has negative effects on consumers of the L2Population
functionality because the L2Population mechanism driver will not be
triggered to publish that a port is UP on a given compute node. Manual
intervention is required in this case.

This patch proposes to handle this by populating the PortContext with
the current binding levels so that the caller can continue on and have
an RPC notification sent out.

Closes-Bug: #1755810
Story: 2003922
Change-Id: Ie2b813b2bdf181fb3c24743dbd13487ace6ee76a
(cherry picked from commit 0dc730c7c0d3f0a49dee28d0d6e7ff9020d94443)

[{'created': '2019-07-30 20:19:37.000000000', 'message': "Fix usage of deprecated devstack function

configure_auth_token_middleware was replaced by
configure_keystone_authtoken_middleware in
Id0dec1ba72467cce5cacfcfdb2bc0af2bd3a3610. Manila's
DevStack plugin no longer needs to create a cache
directory to use as the signing_dir for keystone
authtoken.

Change-Id: I18fa04e6c3a832e17ade3f84d8b43b15686f06fe
"}]
commit_message:
Fix usage of deprecated devstack function

configure_auth_token_middleware was replaced by
configure_keystone_authtoken_middleware in
Id0dec1ba72467cce5cacfcfdb2bc0af2bd3a3610. Manila's
DevStack plugin no longer needs to create a cache
directory to use as the signing_dir for keystone
authtoken.

Change-Id: I18fa04e6c3a832e17ade3f84d8b43b15686f06fe

commit_message:
add support for auth_receipts and multi-method auth

- new exception when an auth receipt is returned.
- a new method for auth receipt.
- support to existing v3 Auth plugins to add additional methods.
- Added a new MultiFactor plugin with loading support which
  takes method names as strings.

Change-Id: Ie6601a50011118e3a07be9752f747c2298ff5230
Closes-Bug: #1839748

the same path as the post-up-down oneshot service file.

commit_message:
Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

[{'created': '2019-05-10 02:39:54.000000000', 'message': '[wip] Add support for Fedora 28

Fedora 28 is the base for CentOS 8.  The rebuild is still in progress
however in order to be able to make sure that we can run it when it
is released, we can start building our tests against Fedora 28.

commit_message:
[wip] Add support for Fedora 28

Fedora 28 is the base for CentOS 8.  The rebuild is still in progress
however in order to be able to make sure that we can run it when it
is released, we can start building our tests against Fedora 28.

Depends-On: I296dd05d675cc23f1aebe606edf5e175fa4b6208

commit_message:
WIP: Enable nova-lxd live migration

To enable lxd instances to migrate between lxd hosts,
each hypervisor must manually add the others.

This patch creates in-memory inventory groups based on
hypervisor type of each compute node.  It then uses
this group to establish the relationship between all
hypervisors.

Change-Id: I077fd96eee24f1dfe0e28d77da762c533517a6e4

to use the project-template instead.

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 20040, 'date': '2017-02-07 08:06:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Matthew: Please let me know if I got this right. Following your
 > insight on _get_usage_dict, I found that the cases based upon
 > instance_type, rather than instance, related to migration. I did
 > perform mass live migrations to upgrade the hypervisors, so this
 > could be an important piece to the puzzle. I re-worded the change
 > to describe this. I still need to fully test this change myself,
 > but I want to know if this looks right to you. Thank you.

Making the change to use instance instead of instance type for this two use cases didn't seem to fix the problem for me after live migration in Newton to a fresh node. However, I made the change locally on the API / conductor / scheduler side, not on the compute side. I'll have to try to understand this better.

In the mean time - the fix to have the DiskFilter not apply for instances that don't need storage has been critical to allowing everything to continue operating normally until this problem is fixed for real. This is why I think it is important now, and important later. This is about minimizing the damage when things do go wrong. Eventually, things go wrong."}, {'account_id': 25089, 'date': '2017-02-26 16:16:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> > Matthew: Please let me know if I got this right. Following your
 > > insight on _get_usage_dict, I found that the cases based upon
 > > instance_type, rather than instance, related to migration. I did
 > > perform mass live migrations to upgrade the hypervisors, so this
 > > could be an important piece to the puzzle. I re-worded the change
 > > to describe this. I still need to fully test this change myself,
 > > but I want to know if this looks right to you. Thank you.
 > 
 > Making the change to use instance instead of instance type for this
 > two use cases didn't seem to fix the problem for me after live
 > migration in Newton to a fresh node. However, I made the change
 > locally on the API / conductor / scheduler side, not on the compute
 > side. I'll have to try to understand this better.
 > 
 > In the mean time - the fix to have the DiskFilter not apply for
 > instances that don't need storage has been critical to allowing
 > everything to continue operating normally until this problem is
 > fixed for real. This is why I think it is important now, and
 > important later. This is about minimizing the damage when things do
 > go wrong. Eventually, things go wrong.

UPDATE: I am still looking into Mathew's last comment. Having _get_usage_dict() calculate based upon the actual device mappings. It isn't a one liner fix, unfortunately.

In the mean time - can you confirm if the changes to use _get_usage_dict() with a instance instead of an instance type are good or not? Matthew had suggested it, but I'm now second guessing based upon whether the event is for a "resize request" or not. In particular, while the calculation for ephemeral storage shouldn't change, what if the vCPU or RAM changes?'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2017-02-27 11:28:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

Thanks for the update, Mark. I like this change better, and I'll be +1 on it with just some additional comments and a change to the commit message.

My concern is about maintainability. In order to function, I often need to trust that code which isn't currently in my 'mental working set' is somewhat sane. When it isn't, I end up making mistakes. Every time we add a workaround rather than fixing the underlying issue we just make the code even more complex. Unfortunately we do that a lot in Nova because it's almost always easier at the time. Consequently, a bunch of code which should be really simple ends up being really complex, because you have to remember all the workarounds every time you touch it. This is why I resist workarounds.

I'm nearly ok with this workaround because it's obvious that it's a workaround for a bug elsewhere, it doesn't introduce any additional context anywhere else, it will continue to work when the underlying issue is fixed even if it isn't removed, and it logs. I will be ok when it's also explicitly commented as a workaround, with a pointer to the bug and where the actual fix is required.

Thanks for the effort on this."}, {'account_id': 25089, 'date': '2017-03-01 06:01:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 25089, 'date': '2017-03-01 06:08:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> Thanks for the update, Mark. I like this change better, and I'll be
 > +1 on it with just some additional comments and a change to the
 > commit message.

I think I've incorporated all your input in patch set 8.

 > My concern is about maintainability. In order to function, I often
 > need to trust that code which isn't currently in my 'mental working
 > set' is somewhat sane. When it isn't, I end up making mistakes.
 > Every time we add a workaround rather than fixing the underlying
 > issue we just make the code even more complex. Unfortunately we do
 > that a lot in Nova because it's almost always easier at the time.
 > Consequently, a bunch of code which should be really simple ends up
 > being really complex, because you have to remember all the
 > workarounds every time you touch it. This is why I resist
 > workarounds.

Understood. It is the compromise between being resilient to external bad influences, and making sure to call out external bad influences. My attempt to compromise here was to log the problem. In the latest iteration, I made it a WARNING. Here is a sample from our OpenStack deployment after I deployed the latest version of this patch:

2017-03-01 00:58:57.384 8002 WARNING nova.scheduler.filters.disk_filter [req-5bb94bef-cfc6-4650-abc2-9c2f43d23307 c3d610ee9324429b98d9b1cf748e9056 2b1b124c6f4b4275a60859b0d3bb1d04
 - - -] (onxstack033.ciena.com, onxstack033.ciena.com) ram: 184120MB disk: -121856MB io_ops: 0 instances: 13 suggests -121856.0 MB  usable disk. Using 0 MB usable disk instead.

You can see how severely negative it is. Without this patch, our deployment would be unusable. With this patch, our deployment is 80%+ usable. We still need to address the real problem, and this will be in the next patch. I will probably need your help, but I will try based upon your direction provided so far.

 > I'm nearly ok with this workaround because it's obvious that it's a
 > workaround for a bug elsewhere, it doesn't introduce any additional
 > context anywhere else, it will continue to work when the underlying
 > issue is fixed even if it isn't removed, and it logs. I will be ok
 > when it's also explicitly commented as a workaround, with a pointer
 > to the bug and where the actual fix is required.

I updated the commit log to describe this. I wasn't sure if you meant in the commit log, or also in the code. I also adjusted the comments in the code to be up-to-date with my current understanding of the problem."}, {'account_id': 20040, 'date': '2017-03-01 06:47:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)

> AFAICT, the bug is here:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1049-L1053
 > I think that should be taking account of block device mappings, but
 > it doesn't. Consequently it doesn't know if root_gb and
 > ephemeral_gb are actually used or not.

Hi Matthew:

I believe I have addressed the underlying problem. With debugging enabled, I have traced each of the cases in our real live environment and this code change seems to be correct. Can you please confirm that this fix aligns with your thinking?

The BlockDeviceMappings were messier than I expected. For example - volume_size seems to be None for the root block device, measured in GB for ephemeral block devices, and measured in MB for swap block devices. I think I have correctly handled each of these.

I could use some advice on the unit tests, as they are failing right now."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-04-04 11:32:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Verified-1

- nova-dvsm-full-tempest http://64.119.130.115/nova/430091/12/ : SUCCESS in 1h 36m 37s'}, {'account_id': 25089, 'date': '2017-04-08 08:01:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 25089, 'date': '2017-04-08 08:11:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)

> Don't have time right now to fully think through the implications
 > of resize here. This could be a can of worms.

There are so many worms in this can! It's broken today, but in more ways that we originally discussed.

For example, the original code before any change presumes that the instance_type information means anything at all. However, I found in our database that we also have instance types with root_gb = 0, and instances with root_gb = 0, but they have local root drives that are as much as 200 GiB! This turns out to be due to Nova interpretation of root_gb = 0 to mean that the local root drive size should be deduced from the image, and then it still stores root_gb = 0 in the database.

The latest update seems to be the best calculation possible. It should be at least as good as Nova does today. I had to apply another patch in another area to have root_gb be set according to the image specifications to get it to show up correctly in the database.

Although the code technically works, and I have seen through debug that many different scenarios are now calculated more correctly than before, I am not sure that this actually solves the underlying problem. I pushed this change out to all Nova compute nodes and restarted openstack-nova-compute on each of them, and although I see them making the right calculations (given the data available), I am still seeing the effects of the storage being over estimated.

I need to study this more, but I wanted to make sure the latest version of this change was uploaded, so people are not still seeing the previous version."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-04-08 09:27:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Verified-1

[{'created': '2017-02-07 06:57:52.000000000', 'message': 'DiskFilter should only check if sufficient available storage exists, if storage has been requested.

Change-Id: I146ee15a89a69aa132b20ae98ad76dba6f63355b
Closes-Bug: 1662432
'}, {'created': '2017-02-08 12:21:26.000000000', 'message': 'DiskFilter should only apply when storage is requested

Change-Id: I146ee15a89a69aa132b20ae98ad76dba6f63355b
Closes-Bug: 1662432
'}, {'created': '2017-02-15 08:28:43.000000000', 'message': 'DiskFilter should only apply when storage is requested

Change-Id: I146ee15a89a69aa132b20ae98ad76dba6f63355b
Closes-Bug: 1662432
'}, {'created': '2017-02-15 08:48:53.000000000', 'message': 'DiskFilter should only apply when storage is requested

Change-Id: I146ee15a89a69aa132b20ae98ad76dba6f63355b
Closes-Bug: 1662432
'}, {'created': '2017-02-16 18:12:48.000000000', 'message': 'DiskFilter should only apply when storage is requested

Ideally, the disk usage calculation will always be correct,
and the DiskFilter will be able to treat "0" the same as any
other disk request. However, if this premise turns out to be
false, the DiskFilter will prevent scheduling of machines.
In extreme cases, the entire compute cluster can prevent
new machines from being scheduled.

In the case we encountered, it was due to a flavor that
permits ephemeral storage, but where many instances chose to
use Cinder volumes instead. In this case, the free_disk_mb
became very negative, and the request for "0" storage was
failing. Every machine in our cluster was eliminated from
scheduling due to this issue.

This change makes DiskFilter more robust. The DiskFilter
should only apply when storage is actually requested. It
should yield the scheduling decision to other filters
when sufficient disk is available, or if no disk is actually
requested.

The underlying miscalculation of disk usage still needs to
be resolved. However, DiskFilter should be robust in case
of this or future miscalculations.

Change-Id: I146ee15a89a69aa132b20ae98ad76dba6f63355b
Closes-Bug: 1662432
'}, {'created': '2017-02-19 07:19:38.000000000', 'message': 'Disk usage miscalculation due to instance migration

During instance migration, the disk usage calculation
has been based upon the instance type rather than the
instance. In the case that the instance type is a
flavor that permits ephemeral storage, but the instance
uses less ephemeral storage than the total permitted,
this can lead to the migration target reserving the
total ephemeral storage permitted for the instance type,
rather than the actual ephemeral storage used by the
instance.

In extreme cases, this can lead to the DiskFilter
preventing scheduling of any new instances to the
target, as the free_disk_mb calculation can become
negative. With a negative free_disk_mb, this prevented
scheduling of all new instances whether or not they
required ephemeral storage.

This change addresses the instance migration issue,
by ensuring that the disk usage calculation is based
upon the instance.

This change further guards the DiskFilter against
current and future miscalculations, by ensuring that
it gracefully handles the situation where free_disk_mb
is less than zero, and at least permits instances to
be scheduled that do no require any ephemeral storage.

Change-Id: I146ee15a89a69aa132b20ae98ad76dba6f63355b
Closes-Bug: 1662432
'}, {'created': '2017-02-19 07:21:44.000000000', 'message': 'Disk usage miscalculation due to instance migration

During instance migration, the disk usage calculation
has been based upon the instance type rather than the
instance. In the case that the instance type is a
flavor that permits ephemeral storage, but the instance
uses less ephemeral storage than the total permitted,
this can lead to the migration target reserving the
total ephemeral storage permitted for the instance type,
rather than the actual ephemeral storage used by the
instance.

In extreme cases, this can lead to the DiskFilter
preventing scheduling of any new instances to the
target, as the free_disk_mb calculation can become
negative. With a negative free_disk_mb, this prevented
scheduling of all new instances whether or not they
required ephemeral storage.

This change addresses the instance migration issue,
by ensuring that the disk usage calculation is based
upon the instance.

This change further guards the DiskFilter against
current and future miscalculations, by ensuring that
it gracefully handles the situation where free_disk_mb

be scheduled that do no require any ephemeral storage.

Change-Id: I146ee15a89a69aa132b20ae98ad76dba6f63355b
Closes-Bug: 1662432
'}, {'created': '2017-03-01 06:01:48.000000000', 'message': 'DiskFilter handling for free space less than zero

Bug 1662432 documents the case where free space calculation can
result in a negative number. Once this situation spreads to all
Nova compute nodes, this can have the effect of preventing any
instances from being scheduled to any Nova compute node in the
cluster.

This change is a work-around to ensure that the cluster will remain
as usable as possible if this situation is encountered.

This change will sanitize the input. If the free space calculation
results in a negative number, a warning will be logged and the free
space will be treated as if it was zero.

This ensures that at least the instances that use Cinder for volume
storage can still be scheduled.

This is not a complete solution to the bug as it does not resolve
the problem for instances that use ephemeral instance storage.

Change-Id: I146ee15a89a69aa132b20ae98ad76dba6f63355b
Partial-Bug: 1662432
'}, {'created': '2017-03-01 08:09:30.000000000', 'message': 'DiskFilter handling for free space less than zero

commit_message:
Resource tracker should use Block Device Mappings

Instances may use less local storage than the flavor
specification permits.

This change corrects the resource tracker to consider
Block Device Mappings when calculating local storage
usage.

Change-Id: I146ee15a89a69aa132b20ae98ad76dba6f63355b
Closes-Bug: 1662432

commit_message:
Run rabbitmq container with rabbitmq user

This change makes rabbitmq container run with the rabbitmq user
instead of the root user. As the rabbitmq user doesn't have write
access to '/run' directory, the templates are updated to use the
'/tmp' directory instead which the rabbitmq user has write access
to.

Change-Id: Ia35c3f741fefe3172c93bb042bf8d26bf7672cfc

commit_message:
Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

Change-Id: I22cf36bae9d46c99d16e92e32d45df8a460b7c84
Story: #2005924
Task: #34225

[{'created': '2019-08-08 18:22:09.000000000', 'message': "reconciler: Enqueue right work for shard containers

This fixes newly-enqueued work going forward, but doesn't offer anything
to try to parse existing bad work items or even to kick shards so they
reset their reconciler high-water marks.

Change-Id: I79d20209cea70a6447c4e94941e5e854889cbec5
Closes-Bug: 1836082
(cherry picked from commit f4bb1bea28640dc603da891559387d6b15f1f2da)
"}]
commit_message:
reconciler: Enqueue right work for shard containers

This fixes newly-enqueued work going forward, but doesn't offer anything
to try to parse existing bad work items or even to kick shards so they
reset their reconciler high-water marks.

Change-Id: I79d20209cea70a6447c4e94941e5e854889cbec5
Closes-Bug: 1836082
(cherry picked from commit f4bb1bea28640dc603da891559387d6b15f1f2da)

doc: Fix 3PAR hpe3par:convert_to_base extra spec is documented

With commit f8084991284acfd8e0cd80ed456a83bcec6d5dcc,
provide convert_to_base extra option during creation
of volume from snapshot.

Closes-Bug: #1836069

commit_message:
lxc: make use of filter python3 compatible

_detect_nbd_devices uses the filter
builtin internally to filter valid devices.

In python 2, filter returns a list. In python 3,
filter returns an iterable or generator function.
This change eagerly converts the result of calling filter
to a list to preserve the python 2 behaviour under python 3.

Closes-Bug: #1840068

Change-Id: I25616c5761ea625a15d725777ae58175651558f8

commit_message:
Fix misuse of nova.objects.base.obj_equal_prims

The nova.objects.base.obj_equal_prims returns True or False.
It does not assert anything.
So the return value should be asserted in tests.

Add assertTrue where the nova.objects.base.obj_equal_prims is called.

Change-Id: I49460ec3b572ee14b32229e771a5499ff91e8722
Closes-Bug: #1839853
(cherry picked from commit 5c1d9dcbb29f5a84d56c4e496b3111b4040cad13)
(cherry picked from commit a8e19afb3d4889412ee6f539bb63865eb8ef5bb5)

In the diskfile module, there are a couple of cases where we would
quarantine the suffix dir if a single object within is not a directory.

Change the code so that we quarantine only the object.

Change-Id: I35eb16f568c00d973eb089aedd0e5a5619c25a2f
(cherry picked from commit 6008b0a83f862b2396ad6642b7863a30a258520b)

commit_message:
Fix quarantine when object path is not a directory

In the diskfile module, there are a couple of cases where we would
quarantine the suffix dir if a single object within is not a directory.

Change the code so that we quarantine only the object.

Change-Id: I35eb16f568c00d973eb089aedd0e5a5619c25a2f
(cherry picked from commit 6008b0a83f862b2396ad6642b7863a30a258520b)

commit_message:
Make sure the port still in port map when prepare_port_filter

The current code will remove the port from sg_port_map, but then it
won't be added into the map, when we resize/migrate this instance,
the related openflow won't be deleted, this will cause vm connectivity
problem.

Closes-Bug: #1825295
Change-Id: I94ddddda3c1960d43893c7a367a81279d429e469
(cherry picked from commit 82782d37639fab97e445e4bbb4daeb85dc829fcd)

commit_message:
Make sure the port still in port map when prepare_port_filter

The current code will remove the port from sg_port_map, but then it
won't be added into the map, when we resize/migrate this instance,
the related openflow won't be deleted, this will cause vm connectivity
problem.

Closes-Bug: #1825295
Change-Id: I94ddddda3c1960d43893c7a367a81279d429e469
(cherry picked from commit 82782d37639fab97e445e4bbb4daeb85dc829fcd)

commit_message:
[Trivial]Remove unused helper _remove_fip_rate_limit_cache

_remove_fip_rate_limit_cache is introduced in ab57410ec8e5fae97dec052a5940debd614e4e50
and is never used after it's created, so this is to remove it
for code clean.

Change-Id: Ie196dd7bff11dd1e742b569b5df2ce047ed057c5

commit_message:
Increase retries to get dlrn repo in emit_releases file

Gate jobs are failing when this script is run from providers
outside of rdocloud. The review increases the timeout and
retries to avoid spordic failures.

Related-Bug: #1839845
Change-Id: I5903b8eee40868f57dcd019dd7ab5cdd9652cabc

commit_message:
Remove tools/test-setup.sh

There is a tools/test-setup.sh file for historical reason which fails
the Trove Jenkins job with the error:

sudo: mysqladmin: command not found

This patch deletes that file as most of the OpenStack projects do.

Change-Id: I8dc53a8c5416b9a4a109e66d5da4f5c470f1d456

[{'created': '2019-08-07 11:50:43.000000000', 'message': 'Make /opt/stack accessible

The trove-scenario tests write to /opt/stack as user stack, change
ownership so that it can be written.

Change-Id: I35e17afb9e827b1fead9d28dbf32f11ce4034a9b
'}, {'created': '2019-08-07 11:51:36.000000000', 'message': 'Make /opt/stack accessible

After [0] devstack no longer changes the ownership of the whole
/opt/stack tree to the stack user unconditionally.

The trove-scenario tests write to /opt/stack as user stack, change
ownership so that it can be written.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/203698

Change-Id: I35e17afb9e827b1fead9d28dbf32f11ce4034a9b
'}, {'created': '2019-08-07 12:01:47.000000000', 'message': 'Fix jobs: make /opt/stack accessible, add bindep

Two changes to get jobs working:

1) After [1] devstack no longer changes the ownership of the whole
   /opt/stack tree to the stack user unconditionally.

   The trove-scenario tests write to /opt/stack as user stack, change
   ownership so that it can be written.

2) Add bindep.txt file. The default fallback file is not installed
   anymore and therefore a bindep.txt file is needed to add install
   additional packages.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/203698
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-June/006888.html

Change-Id: I35e17afb9e827b1fead9d28dbf32f11ce4034a9b
'}, {'created': '2019-08-07 12:34:19.000000000', 'message': 'Fix jobs: make /opt/stack accessible, add bindep

Changes to get jobs working

1) After [1] devstack no longer changes the ownership of the whole
   /opt/stack tree to the stack user unconditionally.

   The trove-scenario tests write to /opt/stack as user stack, change
   ownership so that it can be written.

2) Add bindep.txt file. The default fallback file is not installed
   anymore and therefore a bindep.txt file is needed to add install
   additional packages.

3) Set SSH_DIR to ansible_user_dir to use the setup .ssh directory

[1] https://review.opendev.org/203698
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-June/006888.html

Change-Id: I35e17afb9e827b1fead9d28dbf32f11ce4034a9b
'}, {'created': '2019-08-07 13:21:19.000000000', 'message': 'Fix jobs: make /opt/stack accessible, add bindep

Changes to get jobs working

1) After [1] devstack no longer changes the ownership of the whole
   /opt/stack tree to the stack user unconditionally.

   The trove-scenario tests write to /opt/stack as user stack, change
   ownership so that it can be written.

2) Add bindep.txt file. The default fallback file is not installed
   anymore and therefore a bindep.txt file is needed to add install

'}, {'created': '2019-08-08 01:08:16.000000000', 'message': "Fix Trove CI jobs

Changes to get jobs working

1) After [1] devstack no longer changes the ownership of the whole
   /opt/stack tree to the stack user unconditionally. Switch to the
   stack user when running integration test.

2) Add bindep.txt file[2]. The default fallback file is not installed
   anymore and therefore a bindep.txt file is needed to add install
   additional packages.

3) Use trovestack script rather than devstack to build image so many
   global variables could be used for consistency. By default, devstack
   won't build image.

4) Remove the tools/test-setup.sh as it is not used any more.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/203698
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-June/006888.html

commit_message:
Fix Trove CI jobs

Changes to get jobs working

1) After [1] devstack no longer changes the ownership of the whole
   /opt/stack tree to the stack user unconditionally. Switch to the
   stack user when running integration test.

2) Add bindep.txt file[2]. The default fallback file is not installed
   anymore and therefore a bindep.txt file is needed to add install
   additional packages.

3) Use trovestack script rather than devstack to build image so many
   global variables could be used for consistency. By default, devstack
   won't build image.

4) Remove the tools/test-setup.sh as it is not used any more.

5) Instance upgrade test keeps failing in CI for some reason, although
   it's always passed on my local environment. In order not to block
   other patches, skip the instance upgrade tests temporarily.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/203698
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-June/006888.html

Change-Id: I35e17afb9e827b1fead9d28dbf32f11ce4034a9b

commit_message:
Sync Sphinx requirement

1. Sync sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.
2. Remove unncessary "=="

Change-Id: Iac246b16befbaeabbc6e2f935a4443475d70e8ea

commit_message:
config: cleanup configuration file

[DEFAULT]/use_stderr: matching default[1]
[DEFAULT]/rootwrap_config: matching default[2]
[DEFAULT]/instance_name_template: matching default[3]
[DEFAULT]/libvirt_vif_type: zero reference in nova code
[libvirt]/use_virtio_for_bridges: matching default[4]
[api]/auth_strategy: matching default[5]

[1]: https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#DEFAULT.use_stderr
[2]: https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#DEFAULT.rootwrap_config
[3]: https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#DEFAULT.instance_name_template
[4]: https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#libvirt.use_virtio_for_bridges
[5]: https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#api.auth_strategy

Change-Id: I5bffb58cba2caafc020c726e9741878361c96497

This attempts to convert the legacy requirements-integration job to be a
native zuulv3 job.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-10 08:14:44.000000000', 'message': 'Fix bug when updating policy in firewall group

When updating the policy in firewall group, the fwg status is inactive
and iptables in the router namespace are not changed. This patch fixes
the above problem.

Change-Id: I1a4bc0a8258fbbc340825cccb6d287c94304d3c5
Closes-Bug: #1836015

commit_message:
Fix bug when updating policy in firewall group

When updating only the policy in firewall group, the 'del-port-ids'
and 'add-port-ids' return empty list, which causes the fwg status
to be inactive and iptables in the router namespace are not changed.
This patch fixes the above problem.

Change-Id: I1a4bc0a8258fbbc340825cccb6d287c94304d3c5
Closes-Bug: #1836015

commit_message:
CI: remove quotation marks from TEMPEST_PLUGINS variable

The has stopped working out of a sudden. We should move to tempest_plugins
zuul variable later on, but it is only available since Stein.

Change-Id: I2cc64580b089566e664d54ea2087878b9cce6666
(cherry picked from commit ac0900add29e5a9098c3a3055fde645e7ad088a4)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-08 23:23:01.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Match ComputeNode.uuid to ironic node uuid in RT"

This reverts commit 9f28727eb75e05e07bad51b6eecce667d09dfb65.
This reverts commit 498413074d1f11688123b6b592d5c204dc7b5ef2.

There is a unique index on the compute_nodes.uuid column which
means we can't have more than one compute_nodes record in the
same DB with the same UUID even if one is soft deleted because
the deleted column is not part of that unique index constraint.

This is a problem with ironic nodes where the node is 1:1 with
the compute node record, and when a node is undergoing maintenance
the driver doesn't return it from get_available_nodes() so the
ComputeManager.update_available_resource periodic task (soft)
deletes the compute node record, but when the node is no longer
under maintenance in ironic and the driver reports it, the
ResourceTracker._init_compute_node code will fail to create the
ComputeNode record again because of the duplicate uuid.

Rather than try to made the ComputeNode.destroy conditionally
do a hard-delete of the DB record if the hypervisor_type is
ironic, which might be a mess for backports, just simply revert
the original change that caused the regression since it was only
for serviceability/debugging purposes (link the ironic node uuid
to the compute node uuid to the resource provider id). Losing that
linkage sucks, but if we're going to do it we need to deal with
this duplicate uuid issue in the compute_nodes table first.

Change-Id: Iafba419fe86446ffe636721f523fb619f8f787b3
Closes-Bug: #1839560
'}, {'created': '2019-08-12 18:41:32.000000000', 'message': "Restore soft-deleted compute node with same uuid

means we can't have more than one compute_nodes record in the

This is a problem with ironic nodes where the node is 1:1 with
the compute node record, and when a node is undergoing maintenance
the driver doesn't return it from get_available_nodes() so the
ComputeManager.update_available_resource periodic task (soft)
deletes the compute node record, but when the node is no longer
under maintenance in ironic and the driver reports it, the
ResourceTracker._init_compute_node code will fail to create the
ComputeNode record again because of the duplicate uuid.

This change handles the DBDuplicateEntry error in compute_node_create
by finding the soft-deleted compute node with the same uuid and
simply updating it to no longer be (soft) deleted.

Closes-Bug: #1839560

Change-Id: Iafba419fe86446ffe636721f523fb619f8f787b3
"}]
commit_message:
Restore soft-deleted compute node with same uuid

There is a unique index on the compute_nodes.uuid column which
means we can't have more than one compute_nodes record in the
same DB with the same UUID even if one is soft deleted because
the deleted column is not part of that unique index constraint.

This is a problem with ironic nodes where the node is 1:1 with
the compute node record, and when a node is undergoing maintenance
the driver doesn't return it from get_available_nodes() so the
ComputeManager.update_available_resource periodic task (soft)
deletes the compute node record, but when the node is no longer
under maintenance in ironic and the driver reports it, the
ResourceTracker._init_compute_node code will fail to create the
ComputeNode record again because of the duplicate uuid.

This change handles the DBDuplicateEntry error in compute_node_create
by finding the soft-deleted compute node with the same uuid and
simply updating it to no longer be (soft) deleted.

Closes-Bug: #1839560

Change-Id: Iafba419fe86446ffe636721f523fb619f8f787b3

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-09 21:54:37.000000000', 'message': "Add functional regression recreate test for bug 1839560

This adds a functional test which recreates bug 1839560
where the driver reports a node, then no longer reports
it so the compute manager deletes it, and then the driver
reports it again later (this can be common with ironic
nodes as they undergo maintenance). The issue is that since
Ia69fabce8e7fd7de101e291fe133c6f5f5f7056a in Rocky, the
ironic node uuid is re-used for the compute node uuid but
there is a unique constraint on the compute node uuid so
when trying to create the compute node once the ironic node
is available again, the compute node create fails with a
duplicate entry error due to the duplicate uuid. To recreate
this in the functional test, a new fake virt driver is added
which provides a predictable uuid per node like the ironic
driver. The test also shows that archiving the database is
a way to workaround the bug until it's properly fixed.

Change-Id: If822509e906d5094f13a8700b2b9ed3c40580431
Related-Bug: #1839560

commit_message:
Add functional regression recreate test for bug 1839560

This adds a functional test which recreates bug 1839560
where the driver reports a node, then no longer reports
it so the compute manager deletes it, and then the driver
reports it again later (this can be common with ironic
nodes as they undergo maintenance). The issue is that since
Ia69fabce8e7fd7de101e291fe133c6f5f5f7056a in Rocky, the
ironic node uuid is re-used for the compute node uuid but
there is a unique constraint on the compute node uuid so
when trying to create the compute node once the ironic node
is available again, the compute node create fails with a
duplicate entry error due to the duplicate uuid. To recreate
this in the functional test, a new fake virt driver is added
which provides a predictable uuid per node like the ironic
driver. The test also shows that archiving the database is
a way to workaround the bug until it's properly fixed.

Change-Id: If822509e906d5094f13a8700b2b9ed3c40580431
Related-Bug: #1839560

commit_message:
ironic-lib: switch to python3

As zeroconf has been updated in SUSE to the python 3.x
only version, we need to switch to Python 3.x.

Also run unit tests to find more issues going forward.

Change-Id: Ibd71b6a82360b25ea9b18a78e3f2355c675e8615

commit_message:
Execute TargetDBSetupTask

This adds the code to CrossCellMigrationTask which
executes the TargetDBSetupTask sub-task and stores
some fields on the main task for use later when
dealing with the target cell.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: I00683acee216c0c0ad87be3eb5ec832f20f054c7
