commit_message:
Run 'tempest-ipv6-only' job in gate

As part of Train community goal 'Support IPv6-Only Deployments and Testing'[1],
Tempest has defined the new job 'tempest-ipv6-only'(adding
in Depends-On patch) which will deploy services on IPv6 and run smoke
tests and IPv6 related tests present in Tempest.

This job will be part of Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Keystone, Glance, Swift
gate.

Verification structure will be:
- 'devstack-IPv6' deploy the service on IPv6
- 'devstack-tempest-ipv6' run will verify the IPv6-only setting and listen address
- 'tempest-ipv6-only' will run the smoke + IPv6 related test case.

This commit adds the new job 'tempest-ipv6-only' run on gate.

Story: #2005477
Task: #35898

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671231/

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/ipv6-support-and-testing.html

Change-Id: I3aff9bf8e23e7c04119c6cd91f1ee3ce6add8eb0

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-06 18:39:38.000000000', 'message': 'Replace non-nova server fault message

The server fault "message" is always shown in the API
server response, regardless of policy or user role.

The fault "details" are only shown to users with the
admin role when the fault code is 500.

The problem with this is for non-nova exceptions, the
fault message is a string-ified version of the exception
(see nova.compute.utils.exception_to_dict) which can
contain sensitive information which the non-admin owner
of the server can see.

This change adds a functional test to recreate the issue
and a change to exception_to_dict which for the non-nova
case changes the fault message by simply storing the
exception type class name. Admins can still see the fault
traceback in the "details" key of the fault dict in the
server API response. Note that _get_fault_details is
changed so that the details also includes the exception
value which is what used to be in the fault message for
non-nova exceptions. This is necessary so admins can still
get the exception message with the traceback details.

Note that nova exceptions with a %(reason)s replacement
variable could potentially be leaking sensitive details as
well but those would need to be cleaned up on a case-by-case
basis since we don't want to change the behavior of all
fault messages otherwise users might not see information
like NoValidHost when their server goes to ERROR status
during scheduling.

SecurityImpact: This change contains a fix for CVE-2019-14433.

NOTE(mriedem): In this backport the functional test is
modified slightly to remove the DiskFilter since we are
using placement for scheduler filtering on DISK_GB.

Change-Id: I5e0a43ec59341c9ac62f89105ddf82c4a014df81
Closes-Bug: #1837877
(cherry picked from commit 298b337a16c0d10916b4431c436d19b3d6f5360e)
(cherry picked from commit 67651881163b75eb1983eaf753471a91ecec35eb)
(cherry picked from commit e0b91a5b1e89bd0506dc6da86bc61f1708f0215a)
(cherry picked from commit 3dcefba60a4f4553888a9dfda9fe3bee094d617a)
(cherry picked from commit 6da28b0aa9b6a0ba67460f88dd2c397605b0679b)
'}]
commit_message:
Replace non-nova server fault message

The server fault "message" is always shown in the API
server response, regardless of policy or user role.

The fault "details" are only shown to users with the
admin role when the fault code is 500.

The problem with this is for non-nova exceptions, the
fault message is a string-ified version of the exception
(see nova.compute.utils.exception_to_dict) which can
contain sensitive information which the non-admin owner
of the server can see.

This change adds a functional test to recreate the issue
and a change to exception_to_dict which for the non-nova
case changes the fault message by simply storing the
exception type class name. Admins can still see the fault
traceback in the "details" key of the fault dict in the
server API response. Note that _get_fault_details is
changed so that the details also includes the exception
value which is what used to be in the fault message for
non-nova exceptions. This is necessary so admins can still
get the exception message with the traceback details.

Note that nova exceptions with a %(reason)s replacement
variable could potentially be leaking sensitive details as
well but those would need to be cleaned up on a case-by-case
basis since we don't want to change the behavior of all
fault messages otherwise users might not see information
like NoValidHost when their server goes to ERROR status
during scheduling.

SecurityImpact: This change contains a fix for CVE-2019-14433.

NOTE(mriedem): In this backport the functional test is
modified slightly to remove the DiskFilter since we are
using placement for scheduler filtering on DISK_GB.

Change-Id: I5e0a43ec59341c9ac62f89105ddf82c4a014df81
Closes-Bug: #1837877
(cherry picked from commit 298b337a16c0d10916b4431c436d19b3d6f5360e)
(cherry picked from commit 67651881163b75eb1983eaf753471a91ecec35eb)
(cherry picked from commit e0b91a5b1e89bd0506dc6da86bc61f1708f0215a)
(cherry picked from commit 3dcefba60a4f4553888a9dfda9fe3bee094d617a)
(cherry picked from commit 6da28b0aa9b6a0ba67460f88dd2c397605b0679b)

commit_message:
Clarify supported SUSE versions

This role only support openSUSE Leap 15, not 42.3, not tumbleweed.
Saying all is confusing and a bad practice. This fixes it, while
ensuring the job is properly defined to test that assertion.

Change-Id: Ib9ff57349126466ecac72859f70d25199828ed0c

subject: [DVR] Add lock during creation of FIP agent gateway port
messages:
[{'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-08-12 08:46:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-08-12 09:26:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Neutron Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Neutron Hyper-V CI

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/675846/1 : FAILURE in 39m 31s'}, {'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2019-08-13 09:14:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-08-13 15:10:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-12 08:46:17.000000000', 'message': "[DVR] Add lock during creation of FIP agent gateway port

In case when new external network is set as gateway network for
dvr router, neutron tries to create floating IP agent gateway port.
There should be always max 1 such port per network per L3 agent but
sometimes when there are 2 requests to set external gateway for 2
different routers executed almost in same time it may happend that
there will be 2 such ports created.
That will cause error with configuration of one of routers on L3 agent
and this will cause e.g. problems with access from VMs to metadata
service.
Such issues are visible in DVR CI jobs from time to time. Please check
related bug for details.

This patch adds lock mechanism during creation of such FIP gateway port.
Such solution isn't fully solving exising race condition as if 2
requests will be processed by api workers running on 2 different nodes
than this race can still happend.
But this should mitigate the issue a bit and solve problem in U/S gates
at least.
For proper fix we should probably add some constraint on database level
to prevent creation of 2 such ports for one network and one host but
such solution will not be easy to backport to stable branches so I would
prefer first to go with this easy workaround.

Conflicts:
    neutron/db/l3_dvr_db.py

Change-Id: Iabab7e4d36c7d6a876b2b74423efd7106a5f63f6

(cherry picked from commit 5c1afcaf2b9cb1bd09267a26dd4f5d7f7e99bf85)

commit_message:
[DVR] Add lock during creation of FIP agent gateway port

In case when new external network is set as gateway network for
dvr router, neutron tries to create floating IP agent gateway port.
There should be always max 1 such port per network per L3 agent but
sometimes when there are 2 requests to set external gateway for 2
different routers executed almost in same time it may happend that
there will be 2 such ports created.
That will cause error with configuration of one of routers on L3 agent
and this will cause e.g. problems with access from VMs to metadata
service.
Such issues are visible in DVR CI jobs from time to time. Please check
related bug for details.

This patch adds lock mechanism during creation of such FIP gateway port.
Such solution isn't fully solving exising race condition as if 2
requests will be processed by api workers running on 2 different nodes
than this race can still happend.
But this should mitigate the issue a bit and solve problem in U/S gates
at least.
For proper fix we should probably add some constraint on database level
to prevent creation of 2 such ports for one network and one host but
such solution will not be easy to backport to stable branches so I would
prefer first to go with this easy workaround.

Conflicts:
    neutron/db/l3_dvr_db.py

Change-Id: Iabab7e4d36c7d6a876b2b74423efd7106a5f63f6
Related-Bug: #1830763
(cherry picked from commit 7b81c1bc67d2d85e03b4c96a8c1c558a2f909836)
(cherry picked from commit f7532f0c927a551ea40e81a35818eb83faba4b5a)
(cherry picked from commit 5c1afcaf2b9cb1bd09267a26dd4f5d7f7e99bf85)

commit_message:
Bump keystoneauth1 minimum to 3.16.0

Because we should always be tracking to the latest ksa anyway, but
also...

...to allow from_conf to to take advantage of retry config options
introduced in [1] and [2].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/666287
[2] https://review.opendev.org/672930

Change-Id: I85669b12a6948ab5accd3d7df71dcbacce413e33

commit_message:
Get ironicclient retry conf from ksa

This commit deprecates

CONF.ironic.api_max_retries     in favor of ksa-derived
CONF.ironic.connect_retries

and

CONF.ironic.api_retry_interval  in favor of ksa-derived
CONF.ironic.connect_retry_delay

These options were introduced via [1] and [2], both of which are
available as of ksa 3.16.0, so the ksa minimum is bumped to that here.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666287/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672930/

Change-Id: Iade0d5ac2b4604b84459b19e8fc77db20e3121e7

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-01 10:31:47.000000000', 'message': 'Correct "repos" validation and adds Molecule tests

The way `yum repolist' works isn't consistent on CentOS-7 and Fedora. On
the first, it does fail on a broken repository, spitting an error on
STDERR and exiting with 1.

On Fedora, it sadly just ignores the failing repository with a single
line, and exits with 0.

This patch intends to make the validation more resilient, and adds
Molecule testing in order to ensure it's actually working as expected.

Change-Id: Ib46f5993eeac6ec39a603da3b8e943c960d7c52d
(cherry picked from commit fa974b9fb9f1e9d3d2ebe5ec5d95095ea018703e)

commit_message:
Correct "repos" validation and adds Molecule tests

The way `yum repolist' works isn't consistent on CentOS-7 and Fedora. On
the first, it does fail on a broken repository, spitting an error on
STDERR and exiting with 1.

On Fedora, it sadly just ignores the failing repository with a single
line, and exits with 0.

This patch intends to make the validation more resilient, and adds
Molecule testing in order to ensure it's actually working as expected.

Depends-On: I0551ab56324ede7f1d33e0e9a680c26ea164023c
Change-Id: Ib46f5993eeac6ec39a603da3b8e943c960d7c52d
(cherry picked from commit fa974b9fb9f1e9d3d2ebe5ec5d95095ea018703e)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-09 11:27:16.000000000', 'message': 'Config updates for elk 7.x

Updated ELK config files to elk 7.x reference samples, bringing over
existing customisation from elk_metrics_6x.

Removed deprecated use of --pipeline in elastic_beat_setup/tasks/main.yml,
--pipeline is no longer a valid cli argument.

Updated logstash-pipelines and removed the dynamic insertion of the date into
index names. This function is now done with the new ILM feature in elasticsearch
rather than logstash.

Installation of each beat creates an ILM policy for that beat and this patch
does not change the default policy. It is possible that the default policy
will exhaust the available storage and future work needs to be done to address
this.

The non-beat elements of the logstash pipeline (syslog, collectd and others)
are not yet updated to be compatible with ILM.

Change-Id: I735b64c2b7b93e23562f35266134a176a00af1b7

Removed deprecated use of --pipeline in elastic_beat_setup/tasks/main.yml,
--pipeline is no longer a valid cli argument.

Updated logstash-pipelines and removed the dynamic insertion of the date into
index names. This function is now done with the new ILM feature in elasticsearch
rather than logstash.

Installation of each beat creates an ILM policy for that beat and this patch
does not change the default policy. It is possible that the default policy
will exhaust the available storage and future work needs to be done to address
this.

The non-beat elements of the logstash pipeline (syslog, collectd and others)
are not yet updated to be compatible with ILM.

commit_message:
Config updates for elk 7.x

Updated ELK config files to elk 7.x reference samples, bringing over
existing customisation from elk_metrics_6x.

Removed deprecated use of --pipeline in elastic_beat_setup/tasks/main.yml,
--pipeline is no longer a valid cli argument.

Updated logstash-pipelines and removed the dynamic insertion of the date into
index names. This function is now done with the new ILM feature in elasticsearch
rather than logstash.

Installation of each beat creates an ILM policy for that beat and this patch
does not change the default policy. It is possible that the default policy
will exhaust the available storage and future work needs to be done to address
this.

The non-beat elements of the logstash pipeline (syslog, collectd and others)
are not yet updated to be compatible with ILM.

Change-Id: I735b64c2b7b93e23562f35266134a176a00af1b7

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-31 22:43:20.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Create instance data in target cell prior to resize

This adds the code to CrossCellMigrationTask to create the
instance related data in the target cell prior to resizing
(spawning) the instance in the target cell. Since we need
to preserve the history of the instance in the target cell
database, we have to explicitly copy over things like instance
actions and migration records.

Note that records created in the target cell database may have
a new id value so anything that needs to be accessed consistently
across both cells will need to rely on the UUID.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: I30916d8d10d70ce25523fa4961007cedbdfe8ad7

'}, {'created': '2019-01-30 00:51:17.000000000', 'message': 'Add TargetDBSetupTask

This adds a conductor task to create the instance related data
in the target cell prior to resizing (spawning) the instance in
the target cell. Since we need to preserve the history of the
instance in the target cell database, we have to explicitly copy
over things like instance actions and migration records.

Note that records created in the target cell database may have
a new id value so anything that needs to be accessed consistently
across both cells will need to rely on the UUID.

There are also some fields that we do not copy over since they
are specific to the source cell, like pci_devices and services.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: I30916d8d10d70ce25523fa4961007cedbdfe8ad7

This adds a conductor task to create the instance related data
in the target cell prior to resizing (spawning) the instance in
the target cell. Since we need to preserve the history of the
instance in the target cell database, we have to explicitly copy
over things like instance actions and migration records.

Note that records created in the target cell database may have
a new id value so anything that needs to be accessed consistently
across both cells will need to rely on the UUID.

There are also some fields that we do not copy over since they
are specific to the source cell, like pci_devices and services.

commit_message:
Add TargetDBSetupTask

This adds a conductor task to create the instance related data
in the target cell prior to resizing (spawning) the instance in
the target cell. Since we need to preserve the history of the
instance in the target cell database, we have to explicitly copy
over things like instance actions and migration records.

Note that records created in the target cell database may have
a new id value so anything that needs to be accessed consistently
across both cells will need to rely on the UUID.

There are also some fields that we do not copy over since they
are specific to the source cell, like pci_devices and services.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: I30916d8d10d70ce25523fa4961007cedbdfe8ad7

commit_message:
Enable ceph dashboard on scenario001

Since we're able to deploy the ceph dashboard triggering
ceph-ansible, this change adds the ceph dashboard environment
on scenario001.

Change-Id: I93a518cec03dfee453569f6de23ddea3d339fb96

revisions:

commit_message:
Add support for global_request_id

Added support for setting global_request_id on a Connection.
If done, this will cause all requests sent to send the request id
header to the OpenStack services. Since Connection can otherwise
be used multi-threaded, add a method global_request that returns
a new Connection based on the old Connection but on which
the new global_request_id has been set. Since a Connection
can be used as a context manager, this also means the global_request
method can be used in with statements.

Change-Id: I70964cdd79741703c0b9b911b3b2f27c248130f0

messages: [{'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2019-08-12 12:23:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-08-12 20:43:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-08-13 16:02:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-12 12:23:34.000000000', 'message': 'Add encoding to local_settings.py

In order to allow usage of non-latin symbols inside local_settings.py
magic comment is required according to PEP263[1]

While this can be overriden on master with config_template (since [2]),
this might be easily backported to earlier releases.

[1] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0263/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672170/

Change-Id: I9b07cf4a1ffdffab752f59e1510796c29a259b45
(cherry picked from commit 7bb294b92a61ea1bebcdce1943f48ffaf5c1cdee)
'}]
commit_message:
Add encoding to local_settings.py

In order to allow usage of non-latin symbols inside local_settings.py
magic comment is required according to PEP263[1]

While this can be overriden on master with config_template (since [2]),
this might be easily backported to earlier releases.

[1] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0263/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672170/

Change-Id: I9b07cf4a1ffdffab752f59e1510796c29a259b45
(cherry picked from commit 7bb294b92a61ea1bebcdce1943f48ffaf5c1cdee)

subject: Add mixed setup for debian based OS
messages:
[{'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2019-08-08 14:32:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2019-08-08 15:53:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2019-08-08 19:54:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2019-08-08 19:58:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-08-09 21:25:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

It's great to have got this working for the ubuntu distro installs. I'm not sure the var name tempest_mixed_setup is particularly readable - this is an alternative with two vars. In this case the var names are more descriptive of what they do and are maybe a bit clearer when used as conditionals on the tasks.

An additional conditional for including the source tasks

  #the plugin install method follows the main install method except for ubuntu where there are no disto packaged plugins
  tempest_plugin_install_method: "{{ ((tempest_install_method == 'distro') and (ansible_os_family | lower == 'debian')) | ternary("source", tempest_install_method) }}"

The conditionals inside tempest_install_source.yml

  #install any source packages into a venv except for plugins that come from source on an ubnutu distro install
  tempest_source_venv_enabled: "{{ ((tempest_install_method == 'distro') and (ansible_os_family | lower == 'debian')) | ternary(false, true) }}"'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2019-08-12 09:46:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-08-13 04:40:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28543, 'date': '2019-08-13 08:36:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-08-13 16:02:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add mixed setup for debian based OS

Since debian/ubuntu do not provide packages for tempest plugins, we are using
mixed setup. We install tempest as a distro package, while installing
tempest plugins from source, but without venv (for system python).
That guarantees that we have all required plugins and do tests.
To accomplish that variable tempest_plugin_install_source was
introduced.

Change-Id: I198190d601cf8a922c3afaa69a3c0e42ab075735

[{'account_id': 26124, 'date': '2019-08-07 04:17:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-08-07 05:25:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/675025/1 : FAILURE in 2h 19m 45s'}, {'account_id': 29084, 'date': '2019-08-08 18:58:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26124, 'date': '2019-08-12 15:41:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-12 15:56:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

-1 since this changes the behavior of allow_resize_to_same_host. The ERROR issue resulting from UnableToMigrateToSelf should be resolved and trigger a reschedule to an alternative host (or do you have reschedules disabled?).

Even if we were going to do this change, it would be a lot simpler to just change the logic in the API:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/52b9359d6c6f387b8b9728c723c9a2501136d605/nova/compute/api.py#L3562

We can detect if we're doing a cold migration because the flavor won't change for a cold migration, so if we wanted to hard-code that you can't cold migrate to the same host, we'd just add some logic in the API. But that changes the behavior or allow_resize_to_same_host and would break vcenter users since they could have 1 or 2 compute services which are managing a vcenter cluster with hundreds of ESXi hosts and 1K+ VMs, so they have no choice but to cold migrate on the same *compute service host* (not ESXi host).

I've laid out an alternative in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666604/ but it needs thought, and wouldn't be backportable since it would rely on a standard trait.

A potential backportable change is to add a [workarounds] config option called "allow_cold_migrate_to_same_host" which defaults to be the same value as "allow_resize_to_same_host" (False by default) which would be the same backward compatible behavior but if you're not using vcenter, e.g. you're using libvirt, you could configure nova with allow_resize_to_same_host=true and allow_cold_migrate_to_same_host=false, and eventually we could deprecate that workaround option with the traits-based capability filtering I talk about in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666604/.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-08-12 16:00:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Yeah, apart from anything else this breaks in the way that Matt describes and that's fairly critical/common functionality for the vmware driver."}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-08-12 18:01:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Build succeeded.

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/675025/2 : SUCCESS in 2h 19m 27s'}, {'account_id': 26124, 'date': '2019-08-12 18:39:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Matt,

Thank you so much for the very detailed comments. Yes, we are using libvirt only, and yes I am for using a separate flag allow_cold_migrate_to_same_host to address the issue. Unable to cold migrate is a real-life operational issue for us, we need to fix it.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-12 21:32:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think this is a better short-term and backportable solution to the problem:

commit_message:
Remove the current host from cold migration target host list

If the current host on which the vm resides is very resource-rich,
nova filters return this host each time when user executes cold migration
even if other hosts can meet the vm requirements, the vm can not be
migrated; and the vm is set to ERROR state if allow_resize_to_same_host
is set to TRUE.

Change-Id: Iffee71fdf7c4044e6333056f5c8310ea6b40f2e3
Closes-Bug: 1748697

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:

on Xenial.

commit_message:
Add support for fields in baremetal get_* resources

Omitting Driver since it does not support fields.

Fixes two issues that used to be hidden by ignored 'params' argument
to Resource.fetch:
* Finding/deleting firewall rules ignore filters
* Incorrect invocation of fetch in DNS

Change-Id: I1f0abaec823be327e0e12a090155f97bc59e3489

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-12 15:57:01.000000000', 'message': 'AIO multinode: Add root user directive to Kubelet

Systemd units run as the root user by default; however, environment
variables in spawned processes are not populated for the root user
unless "User=root" is specified for a particular unit [0]. This change
adds the "User=root" declaration to the Kubelet systemd unit so that
Kubelet will look in the root user's home directory for Docker
configuration information. Without this change, Docker configuration
information, such as authentication keys for private repositories, are
ignored by Kubelet even though the Docker daemon honors them.

[0] https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.exec.html#Environment%20variables%20in%20spawned%20processes

Change-Id: I209de0f4f04c078d39b1e8bf18195e51e965cbf3
Signed-off-by: Drew Walters <andrew.walters@att.com>
'}]
commit_message:
AIO multinode: Add root user directive to Kubelet

Systemd units run as the root user by default; however, environment
variables in spawned processes are not populated for the root user
unless "User=root" is specified for a particular unit [0]. This change
adds the "User=root" declaration to the Kubelet systemd unit so that
Kubelet will look in the root user's home directory for Docker
configuration information. Without this change, Docker configuration
information, such as authentication keys for private repositories, are
ignored by Kubelet even though the Docker daemon honors them.

[0] https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.exec.html#Environment%20variables%20in%20spawned%20processes

Change-Id: I209de0f4f04c078d39b1e8bf18195e51e965cbf3
Signed-off-by: Drew Walters <andrew.walters@att.com>

(4 comments)

My -1 is not a strong one. You can find inline comments for some clarification on the behaviors. I believe it would help the code review later.'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2019-08-09 08:51:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Workflow-1

(1 comment)

I realized two problems with this version:

1) Please see Akihiro's comment and my answer in ps5, line 687.

2) The api-ref doc template format and python-neutronclient both made me realize that every single request body in neutron today is a dict on the top level. None of them is a list on the top level. This was probably meant as a measure for upcoming API changes - it's simpler to add/remove dict keys then completely change the topmost type of a request body.

Here now we have a body like this:
[route1, route2, ...]

We could wrap it in a dict like:
{'routes': [route1, route2, ...]}

But if we wrapped it like this:

{'router': {'routes': [route1, route2, ...]}}

then the request bodies would actually be the same as they were on the old extraroute API. Plus the request and response format would be the same too.

So I'm very much inclined to change to the last format before we merge this."}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2019-08-09 12:25:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2019-08-09 12:26:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-12 05:35:18.000000000', 'message': 'Profile Oslo Service processes

This patch enables profiling (capturing function call trace like
cProfile [1]) worker processes on the fly while service is running.
User requests the oslo service process to start profiling by writing
"prof()" command to backdoor socket, once the service (like
neutron-server) finishes expected processing (example finishing API
call), user again writes "prof()" command with file name as argument
to dump the function calltrace stats. Stats file (in pstat format
with user provided filename by adding .prof) will be generated in
temp directory.

For example, to profile neutron server process,
1) echo "prof()" | nc localhost 8002
2) Issue neutron command (or run rally scenarios tests)
   neutron net-create n1
   neutron port-create --name p1 n1
   neutron port-delete p1
   neutron net-delete n1
3) echo "prof('neutron')" | nc localhost 8002
where 8002 is the port which we set like below in neutron.conf
backdoor_port=8002

We can later print the stats from the trace file like below
stats = pstats.Stats('/tmp/neutron.prof')
stats.print_stats()
The trace file will look like in (for above neutron API calls) [2].

We use Yappi with context set to greenlet [3] to profile greenlets.
We can't use GreenletProfiler [4], which does the same [5]
1) as it is no more maintained
2) Also compiling yappi source inside GreenletProfiler is failing for
   python3.

[1] https://docs.python.org/2/library/profile.html
[2] https://gist.github.com/venkataanil/64d5e672bf0206dc151e73fc1058a983
[3] https://bitbucket.org/sumerc/yappi/pull-requests/3
[4] https://pypi.org/project/GreenletProfiler/
[5] https://emptysqua.re/blog/greenletprofiler/

Depends-On: Ibea0cdb732923f1b53d5cb6aeeb4041fb5973494
Change-Id: Id2418093494f1e233a653f6c73bd6894e4a40184
(cherry picked from commit a04daefbb158e955dcfe7379e2b38c272ff31da2)
'}]
commit_message:
Profile Oslo Service processes

This patch enables profiling (capturing function call trace like
cProfile [1]) worker processes on the fly while service is running.
User requests the oslo service process to start profiling by writing
"prof()" command to backdoor socket, once the service (like
neutron-server) finishes expected processing (example finishing API
call), user again writes "prof()" command with file name as argument
to dump the function calltrace stats. Stats file (in pstat format
with user provided filename by adding .prof) will be generated in
temp directory.

For example, to profile neutron server process,
1) echo "prof()" | nc localhost 8002
2) Issue neutron command (or run rally scenarios tests)
   neutron net-create n1
   neutron port-create --name p1 n1
   neutron port-delete p1
   neutron net-delete n1
3) echo "prof('neutron')" | nc localhost 8002
where 8002 is the port which we set like below in neutron.conf
backdoor_port=8002

We can later print the stats from the trace file like below
stats = pstats.Stats('/tmp/neutron.prof')
stats.print_stats()
The trace file will look like in (for above neutron API calls) [2].

We use Yappi with context set to greenlet [3] to profile greenlets.
We can't use GreenletProfiler [4], which does the same [5]
1) as it is no more maintained
2) Also compiling yappi source inside GreenletProfiler is failing for
   python3.

[1] https://docs.python.org/2/library/profile.html
[2] https://gist.github.com/venkataanil/64d5e672bf0206dc151e73fc1058a983
[3] https://bitbucket.org/sumerc/yappi/pull-requests/3
[4] https://pypi.org/project/GreenletProfiler/
[5] https://emptysqua.re/blog/greenletprofiler/

Depends-On: Ibea0cdb732923f1b53d5cb6aeeb4041fb5973494
Change-Id: Id2418093494f1e233a653f6c73bd6894e4a40184
(cherry picked from commit a04daefbb158e955dcfe7379e2b38c272ff31da2)

commit_message:
Add ansible-role-uwsgi project

As a part of OpenStack-Ansible this project will be used to deploy
uwsgi for services. Since uwsgi a common service it makes sense to move
it's management into a separate role.

Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/676193
Change-Id: Idd9f80cf0ea3208921d90af0fc44186978f72b77

commit_message:
Allows to disable in-flight validations

This patches adds the possibility to deactivate in-flight validations by
skipping the "opendev-validation" ansible tag.

It does it in a generic way, meaning we might pass other tags to skip.

Change-Id: I6f3e4fb279146a0f292818929092d1aeb1d3fced
(cherry picked from commit 04b106cb97aea0a5a09d6fcddc5e42a42a543e69)

Update docs & upgrade scripts for Stein

Updating WSREP SST method to rsync which is backward compatible between
galera version 10.1 and 10.3.

commit_message:
Cleanup deprecated opts of keystone_authtoken section

The use of [keystone_authtoken] credentials for trust creation is now
 deprecated. refer to [1][2][3]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/sahara/blob/d16f07ea3ce448033774b69c142453cc7fa79383/releasenotes/notes/trustee-conf-section-5994dcd48a9744d7.yaml
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/sahara/latest/configuration/descriptionconfig.html
[3] https://github.com/openstack/sahara/blob/d60a3b152b4ff3ba48cb9199eac1aad8e182f6e1/sahara/utils/openstack/keystone.py#L116

Change-Id: I9bb2d60fad48b8971f01b2dac6afaad6bbbf0977

consistency.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-06 18:39:38.000000000', 'message': "fix unshelve notification test instability

The unshelve notification sample test shelve-offloads an instance, waits for
it state to change to SHELVED_OFFLOADED then unshelve the instance and matches
generated the unshelve notification with the stored sample. This test
intermittently fails as the host paramter of the instance doesn't match
sometimes. The reason is that the compute manager during shelve offloading
first sets the state of the instance then later sets the host of the instance.
So the test can start unshelving the instance before the host is cleaned by
the shelve offload code.

The test is updated to not just wait for the state change but also wait for
the change of the host attribute.

Change-Id: I459332de407187724fd2962effb7f3a34751f505
Closes-Bug: #1704423
(cherry picked from commit da57d17e6c7d5d7e84af3c46a836ee587581bf8d)
"}]
commit_message:
fix unshelve notification test instability

The unshelve notification sample test shelve-offloads an instance, waits for
it state to change to SHELVED_OFFLOADED then unshelve the instance and matches
generated the unshelve notification with the stored sample. This test
intermittently fails as the host paramter of the instance doesn't match
sometimes. The reason is that the compute manager during shelve offloading
first sets the state of the instance then later sets the host of the instance.
So the test can start unshelving the instance before the host is cleaned by
the shelve offload code.

The test is updated to not just wait for the state change but also wait for
the change of the host attribute.

Change-Id: I459332de407187724fd2962effb7f3a34751f505
Closes-Bug: #1704423
(cherry picked from commit da57d17e6c7d5d7e84af3c46a836ee587581bf8d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-12 12:05:58.000000000', 'message': 'Populate binding levels when concurrent ops fail

Concurrent calls to _bind_port_if_needed may lead to a missing RPC
notification which can cause a port stuck in a DOWN state. If the only
caller that succeeds in the concurrency does not specify that an RPC
notification is allowed then no RPC would be sent to the agent. The
other caller which needs to send an RPC notification will fail since the
resulting PortContext instance will not have any binding levels set.

The failure has negative effects on consumers of the L2Population
functionality because the L2Population mechanism driver will not be
triggered to publish that a port is UP on a given compute node. Manual
intervention is required in this case.

This patch proposes to handle this by populating the PortContext with
the current binding levels so that the caller can continue on and have
an RPC notification sent out.

Closes-Bug: #1755810
Story: 2003922
Change-Id: Ie2b813b2bdf181fb3c24743dbd13487ace6ee76a
(cherry picked from commit 0dc730c7c0d3f0a49dee28d0d6e7ff9020d94443)
'}]
commit_message:
Populate binding levels when concurrent ops fail

Concurrent calls to _bind_port_if_needed may lead to a missing RPC
notification which can cause a port stuck in a DOWN state. If the only
caller that succeeds in the concurrency does not specify that an RPC
notification is allowed then no RPC would be sent to the agent. The
other caller which needs to send an RPC notification will fail since the
resulting PortContext instance will not have any binding levels set.

The failure has negative effects on consumers of the L2Population
functionality because the L2Population mechanism driver will not be
triggered to publish that a port is UP on a given compute node. Manual
intervention is required in this case.

This patch proposes to handle this by populating the PortContext with
the current binding levels so that the caller can continue on and have
an RPC notification sent out.

Closes-Bug: #1755810
Story: 2003922
Change-Id: Ie2b813b2bdf181fb3c24743dbd13487ace6ee76a
(cherry picked from commit 0dc730c7c0d3f0a49dee28d0d6e7ff9020d94443)

commit_message:
Update docs building

Use sphinx-build and cleanup unused config.
Switch to openstackdocstheme 1.20.0 and remove obsolete settings from
conf.py files.

commit_message:
Remove outdated italian page

The Italian page only links to
https://docs.openstack.org/it/upstream-training/ which was last
published over two years ago and thus is really outdated. Remove the
page completely and the link to it, we should not have such old pages
up.

Change-Id: I5f8816737e6b9895c37137d408e78a61a48323b2

commit_message:
Add listeners scenarios for Octaiva

Add the following scenarios for Octavia:

- Octavia.create_and_list_listeners
- Octavia.create_and_delete_listeners
- Octavia.create_and_update_listeners
- Octavia.create_and_show_listeners

Co-author: Lucas H. Xu <hanxu@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5e67c85a76dd6ab9a4940521447545e1f54d1d58
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chucks@redhat.com>
               Lucas H. Xu <hanxu@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

Change-Id: Icd848acb737e046e76e5496f3acd02e1437b7349

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-12 07:10:26.000000000', 'message': "Update port_status to ACTIVE during live-migration

During live-migration nova waits for 'network-vif-plugged' event
in order to proceeed with live-migration [1]. While using OVN
it never happened because the original design assumes usage
of neutron agents.

This patch updates port status from DOWN to ACTIVE during
pre_live_migration state, which in fact for Neutron/ML2
is done by neutron-ovs-agent, just only to emit
'network-vif-plugged' notification and allow nova
to perform live-migration.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/558001/

Change-Id: Ib9fe6e1bfea1d5f62b2f2b6fdb12d16878108c3f
Related-Bug: 1834045
(cherry picked from commit 229f894ee6aff6b5da8cc399575537feed1c6a49)
"}]
commit_message:
Update port_status to ACTIVE during live-migration

During live-migration nova waits for 'network-vif-plugged' event
in order to proceeed with live-migration [1]. While using OVN
it never happened because the original design assumes usage
of neutron agents.

This patch updates port status from DOWN to ACTIVE during
pre_live_migration state, which in fact for Neutron/ML2
is done by neutron-ovs-agent, just only to emit
'network-vif-plugged' notification and allow nova
to perform live-migration.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/558001/

Change-Id: Ib9fe6e1bfea1d5f62b2f2b6fdb12d16878108c3f
Related-Bug: 1834045
(cherry picked from commit 229f894ee6aff6b5da8cc399575537feed1c6a49)

commit_message:
Ceph grafana service certificate request

This change adds the certmonger ceph_grafana class to
define the necessary requirements to make the cert request
for the ceph dashboard service.

Change-Id: Ib5f780349c12eebbf514a75293d8f4644dc5731f

commit_message:
Move scenario007-standalone job to os_tempest

We merged scenario007-standalone in [1] and this changes it to
use os-tempest. Also add tempest_private_net_provider_type to
featureset_override so we can set vxlan for OVS as default is
OVN specific (geneve).

After this we can consider moving to gate and voting.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/631497
Change-Id: I3f1386f7d2571796871e463e25a45f59bff7925a

[{'created': '2019-08-07 13:39:20.000000000', 'message': "Fix discovery cache sharing

The intent is that connect_as shares the discovery cache so that
users don't pay the double cost. Unfortunately, that's not actually
what we were doing. There was also a mistaken thought that we should
be sharing a Session, but we can't do that, because the Session
has the Auth, and what we're doing is making a new Auth.

Attach the discovery_cache to the new Session directly and all
is good.

commit_message:
Fix discovery cache sharing

The intent is that connect_as shares the discovery cache so that
users don't pay the double cost. Unfortunately, that's not actually
what we were doing. There was also a mistaken thought that we should
be sharing a Session, but we can't do that, because the Session
has the Auth, and what we're doing is making a new Auth.

Attach the discovery_cache to the new Session directly and all
is good.

Change-Id: I07a362ea710b01d3588b06e9d3e0f1ce7eb101d4

docker, unless all volume paths exist.

commit_message:
Create missing directories before mounting them

When deploying with podman, we need to create directories if they don't
exist before trying to mount them later when containers are starting.
Otherwise, podman fails with this kind of error:
error checking path \"/etc/iscsi\": stat /etc/iscsi: no such file or directory"

Related-Bug: #1811713
Change-Id: I7dbdc7f3646dda99c8014b4c8ca2edd48778b392
(cherry picked from commit 24f5a255c954a94d69768b139a113113d4e37c80)

commit_message:
Revert "Ensure we get a subnet for ctlplane"

This reverts commit 9e5efd591101928daa7337f4b7a4b076fab24ff8.

The issue was caused by out-dated downstream documentation, and this
change might introduce a regression.

Change-Id: Idc259bfd6c92762d833419f0aab8f5404ee7e801

commit_message:
Add source option for iptables setup

We have some service setting this source in tripleo-heat-templates
this change allows the heat templates to define source information
as needed.

Change-Id: I3408781f5b82faaa00aa857a4a712848dbd97172
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin@cloudnull.com>

commit_message:
Support for Router Scheduling on addition/removal of chassis

The following patch provides L3HA Rescheduling of gateways when chassis
are added/removed. It reschedules the gateway ports when a new chassis
is added/old one removed. However, the number of chassis where a
gateway can be hosted is limited by the constant MAX_GW_CHASSIS.

Co-Authored-By: Maciej Józefczyk <mjozefcz@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I0d96efe4ceef4168039930738285c19d5c003951
Closes-Bug: #1762691

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-07 00:49:40.000000000', 'message': 'fix update port bug

when update port set body={"port": {}}, neutron server will return 500.

In function _process_port_binding_attributes(plugins/ml2/plugin.py),
when update port body={"port": {}}
attrs={}
vnic_type = attrs and attrs.get(portbindings.VNIC_TYPE)
vnic_type = {}
because attrs as False, will not execute attrs.get(portbindings.VNIC_TYPE)
vnic_type will be replicated as attrs.

Change-Id: I40d388543387ebdd72f26d761339c1829bef9413
Partial-bug: #1838396
(cherry picked from commit dd080c70b423a56a69abf7e52d1fee0cb7988c92)
'}]
commit_message:
fix update port bug

when update port set body={"port": {}}, neutron server will return 500.

In function _process_port_binding_attributes(plugins/ml2/plugin.py),
when update port body={"port": {}}
attrs={}
vnic_type = attrs and attrs.get(portbindings.VNIC_TYPE)
vnic_type = {}
because attrs as False, will not execute attrs.get(portbindings.VNIC_TYPE)
vnic_type will be replicated as attrs.

Change-Id: I40d388543387ebdd72f26d761339c1829bef9413
Partial-bug: #1838396
(cherry picked from commit dd080c70b423a56a69abf7e52d1fee0cb7988c92)

commit_message:
fix update port bug

when update port set body={"port": {}}, neutron server will return 500.

In function _process_port_binding_attributes(plugins/ml2/plugin.py),
when update port body={"port": {}}
attrs={}
vnic_type = attrs and attrs.get(portbindings.VNIC_TYPE)
vnic_type = {}
because attrs as False, will not execute attrs.get(portbindings.VNIC_TYPE)
vnic_type will be replicated as attrs.

Change-Id: I40d388543387ebdd72f26d761339c1829bef9413
Partial-bug: #1838396
(cherry picked from commit dd080c70b423a56a69abf7e52d1fee0cb7988c92)

commit_message:
Stop OVS agent before starting it again

In TestOVSAgent, there are two tests where the OVS agent is
configured and started twice per test. Before the second call,
the agent should be stopped first.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/667216/
Change-Id: I30c2bd4ce3715cde60bc0cd3736bd9c75edc1df3
Closes-Bug: #1830895
(cherry picked from commit b77c79e5e8ee8127ccfc875e6e260f554694104b)
(cherry picked from commit ff662050817eee6ee6371e765b46d90e49adbe9c)

commit_message:
Stop OVS agent before starting it again

In TestOVSAgent, there are two tests where the OVS agent is
configured and started twice per test. Before the second call,
the agent should be stopped first.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/667216/
Change-Id: I30c2bd4ce3715cde60bc0cd3736bd9c75edc1df3
Closes-Bug: #1830895
(cherry picked from commit b77c79e5e8ee8127ccfc875e6e260f554694104b)
(cherry picked from commit ff662050817eee6ee6371e765b46d90e49adbe9c)

Moving to +1, re: colleen's comments. I think we're going to need to wait on the other fixes for group-assignment / user assignments with TTL attached to land a real fix for this."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-07-10 21:47:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-07-10 21:52:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I've restored the original patchset for this fix, and I'd like to argue that it is correct and safe with federated users until we have https://review.opendev.org/604201 implemented.

With or without this patch, federated users with a group-only role assignment can't create application credentials. This is because there is a safeguard in the application credentials API that uses the assignment driver to query the user's  role assignments:

https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/src/commit/e9ee189b4392bbd9ff4324cb194ee9e1e0818586/keystone/application_credential/core.py#L73-L76

This query is already looking for *effective* role assignments. It fails for federated group-only users because the group membership is ephemeral - querying the SQL driver returns nothing, because the group membership is attained through the mapping.

So, federated users with group-only assignments can't make use of this until 604201 is solved. Even if this safeguard wasn't in place for the creation of application credentials, the list_role_assignments call in the token model still wouldn't return these ephemeral role assignments since it is querying the assignment backend and not the ephemeral mapping."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-07-11 03:42:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2019-08-06 16:43:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

One Nitpick. Otherwise looks good.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-08-06 16:54:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-08-06 16:54:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Allows to use application credentials through group membership

When using role assignment through groups, the user cannot use
the application credentials created. This allows to look up
the membership by checking inherited and group assignments.

Change-Id: If1bf5bd785a494923303265797311d42018ba7af
Closes-Bug: #1773967

messages: [{'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-12 19:15:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-08-13 09:23:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2019-08-13 12:36:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-12 19:15:24.000000000', 'message': "DRY test_connection

An earlier change [1] wastefully subclassed TestConnection when all it
needed was the setUp(). The subclass was redundantly running all the
superclass's tests again.

This commit factors out the setUp into a local base class and subclasses
that base class from TestConnection and TestOsloConfig, cutting out 14
redundant tests.

[1] I3d16d17caa2e8a58b7064c54e930468288aa6ff1

Change-Id: If65d7c23e07d9f232410a562e47f183d003a7dc0
"}]
commit_message:
DRY test_connection

An earlier change [1] wastefully subclassed TestConnection when all it
needed was the setUp(). The subclass was redundantly running all the
superclass's tests again.

This commit factors out the setUp into a local base class and subclasses
that base class from TestConnection and TestOsloConfig, cutting out 14
redundant tests.

[1] I3d16d17caa2e8a58b7064c54e930468288aa6ff1

Change-Id: If65d7c23e07d9f232410a562e47f183d003a7dc0

commit_message:
Adds prefixlen to the request body when creating subnets

The python-openstack client uses the OpenStack SDK to interface with
Neutron, which strips the prefix length from the client request when
creating a subnet from a subnet pool. This patch adds support for
prefixlen when creating a subnet.

Conflicts:
	openstack/cloud/openstackcloud.py

Partial-Bug: 1754062

Change-Id: I87762c55ea7b24eefbd91fc159cf57a5566ce5f4
(cherry picked from commit b668add5a9fab0c759a2f863ebf5a60c8c9ee168)

commit_message:
Adds prefixlen to the request body when creating subnets

The python-openstack client uses the OpenStack SDK to interface with
Neutron, which strips the prefix length from the client request when
creating a subnet from a subnet pool. This patch adds support for
prefixlen when creating a subnet.

Conflicts:
	openstack/cloud/openstackcloud.py

Partial-Bug: 1754062

Change-Id: I87762c55ea7b24eefbd91fc159cf57a5566ce5f4
(cherry picked from commit b668add5a9fab0c759a2f863ebf5a60c8c9ee168)

commit_message:
Revert "Ensure we get a subnet for ctlplane"

This reverts commit 2a684c0b888ca0cf5277d1e6b5d6d689dccb7496.

The issue was caused by out-dated downstream documentation, and this
change might introduce a regression.

commit_message:
Add ContainerImagePrepare service to CellController role

The CellController role does not have ContainerImagePrepare
service. This result in empty external_deploy_steps_tasks.yaml
and does not update container images when trying to update
the cell stack.

Change-Id: Ib12d99be11e34b77fe3697c9ce09f84e4a1294f3
Closes-Bug: 1839789

commit_message:
Add optional pre-commit config

There are people who enjoy running pre-commit hooks. I am not one
of them, but they exist. Nova has a patch up to also add an
optional config, so why not add one for ourselves.

This does not use the builtin flake8 check from pre-commit which
pulls in a much newer version than hacking does.

Change-Id: I0d8b2dda27ef5cf2bb0c8c78ec505d12d2f44af1

commit_message:
Protect imports in __init__ inside factory

Otherwise importing flake8 hooks requires all dependencies being
installed. We're only importing these submodules for the factory.

Change-Id: I66284945f6e309161ffc270dddb73547ff215996

[{'created': '2019-08-09 13:57:23.000000000', 'message': "Check for rc instead of |succeeded

We went from `ignore_errors: true` to `failed_when: false` to prevent
Ansible printing errors which aren't really errors. When using
`succeeded` filter on a registered variable from such task, we will
always get true, which is not what we want. Check for `.rc == 0`
instead to set the facts as they were intended.

Change-Id: Ib8dea68720fda86cf4fd879cdf194d206968f6fb
Partial-Bug: #1831690
"}]
commit_message:
Check for rc instead of |succeeded

We went from `ignore_errors: true` to `failed_when: false` to prevent
Ansible printing errors which aren't really errors. When using
`succeeded` filter on a registered variable from such task, we will
always get true, which is not what we want. Check for `.rc == 0`
instead to set the facts as they were intended.

Change-Id: Ib8dea68720fda86cf4fd879cdf194d206968f6fb
Partial-Bug: #1831690

commit_message:
use payloads for ROUTER_GATEWAY events

This patch switches the code over to the payload style of callbacks [1]
for ROUTER_GATEWAY events for those that are not using them yet.
The unit tests are also updated where needed to account for the
payload style callbacks and publish() method. Finally the patch
normalizes the passing of gateway IPs which are currently referred to
as 'gw_ips' and 'gateway_ips' depending on the event; now all events use
'gateway_ips'.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/638274/

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron-lib/latest/contributor/callbacks.html

Change-Id: I8f797f31b3413e4879400ad2832539314d6e9cfc

commit_message:
Handle when upgrade_prepare_extra_params is a string.

If for some reason, the upgrade_prepare_extra_params
parameter is passed as a string instead of a list, then
the string will be appended in the overcloud_upgrade_prepare.sh script in
the way 'character' -> -e c -e h -e a -e r -e c -e t -e r .
For that reason we need to add the logic to handle the string
as a list to properly work.

Change-Id: I8c1e671cadd0413a06a67766b0461bdbdeac3d32

commit_message:
Add post undercloud OS upgrade workarounds.

It would be useful to unset some of the workarounds set
prior to the Undercloud OS upgrade. For that reason a new
workarounds section is created post_undercloud_os_upgrade.

Change-Id: I56995623b3430d96d226ff46b4aea62222ab4a9e

commit_message:
Software RAID: Handle empty target_raid_config

If the target_raid_config is empty, we should not try
to create software RAID devices.

Change-Id: I5a29dc34a07903be0cc1b19594f160ac63c6ed2d

commit_message:
Increase wait reboot timeout

By this patch we increase to 800 seconds the wait for
undercloud after OS upgrade reboot

Change-Id: Ieccdfed5e5c78271a30cd3b67762ad4eb7578028

messages:
[{'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-12 18:03:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-07-12 18:04:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-12 20:58:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Thanks for the contribution. Can you please log a bug on LP[1] and add more details in bug as well as in commit msg. 

Please let me know if you need any help. 

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-12 21:23:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-12 21:24:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-12 21:25:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2019-07-15 01:54:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Thanks for your work, and, I wonder how "if a username
for the project and the username in tempest.conf or
accounts.yaml are not identical" can happen?'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-15 15:36:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Thanks for your work, and, I wonder how "if a username
 > for the project and the username in tempest.conf or
 > accounts.yaml are not identical" can happen?

If a project is created by one person and some one else generates a tempest.conf or accounts.yaml for that project with a change in the case of username, that's where this patchset can be useful.'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-15 16:29:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Thanks for your work, and, I wonder how "if a username
 > for the project and the username in tempest.conf or
 > accounts.yaml are not identical" can happen?

 > Thanks for the contribution. Can you please log a bug on LP[1] and
 > add more details in bug as well as in commit msg.
 > 
 > Please let me know if you need any help.
 > 
 > [1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest

Here's the link https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1836618 to the bug I logged and also added the description in the commit message.'}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2019-07-16 08:24:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm not sure whether the username should be case insensitive, so let's just wait for other opinions."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-16 11:47:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

> I'm not sure whether the username should be case insensitive, so
 > let's just wait for other opinions.


If it is not case sensitive in keystone then we can fix the assert in Tempest tests otherwise it is configuration error."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-16 14:26:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)

cmurphy mentioned on IRC about the keystone doc about case sensitive of keystone resource - https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/case-insensitive.html

Let's fix the Tempest assert."}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-16 16:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-16 16:16:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > cmurphy mentioned on IRC about the keystone doc about case
 > sensitive of keystone resource - https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/case-insensitive.html
 > 
 > Let's fix the Tempest assert.

I fixed the lines to be having less than 79 characters and added a link to the bug in commit message."}, {'account_id': 29441, 'date': '2019-07-16 20:19:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-16 21:02:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29441, 'date': '2019-07-16 22:01:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

recheck'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-16 22:14:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-17 04:03:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

Thanks. lgtm'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-17 04:03:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2019-07-17 05:36:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I read https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/case-insensitive.html, in which it says "PostgreSQL is case-sensitive by default", that means if we use PostgreSQL as the backend, the username is not case-insensitive? So is it suiltable to change Tempest to be case-insensitive?'}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2019-07-17 05:37:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

Just soft -1 to get my upper question answered:)'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-17 17:13:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7: Patch Set 6 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-17 20:17:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-17 21:56:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> I read https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/case-insensitive.html,
 > in which it says "PostgreSQL is case-sensitive by default", that
 > means if we use PostgreSQL as the backend, the username is not
 > case-insensitive? So is it suiltable to change Tempest to be
 > case-insensitive?

This is testing Keystone token. The username passed into the GetToken call will act as a validation to the case-sensitive or case-insensitive username. I am just lowercasing the names for data stores that are case-insensitive, so the tests do not fail.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-18 02:49:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2

> I read https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/case-insensitive.html,
 > in which it says "PostgreSQL is case-sensitive by default", that
 > means if we use PostgreSQL as the backend, the username is not
 > case-insensitive? So is it suiltable to change Tempest to be
 > case-insensitive?

Actually test is comparing the config value with keystone stored value. Keystone always preserves the case sensitive. If we compare the values returned from keystone then we can take care of case-sensitive.

For example if keystone has user 'user' and someone config that name in tempest.conf as 'User' then both are same because you cannot create two users with 'user' and 'User' name in keystone.'}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2019-07-18 03:17:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

as to "because you cannot create two users with 'user' and 'User' name in keystone.", the doc says that 
"PostgreSQL¶
PostgreSQL is case-sensitive by default, so if a project by the name of “myproject” is created with the existing “mYpRoJeCt”, it will be created successfully."'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-18 03:31:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

> as to "because you cannot create two users with 'user' and 'User'
 > name in keystone.", the doc says that
 > "PostgreSQL¶
 > PostgreSQL is case-sensitive by default, so if a project by the
 > name of “myproject” is created with the existing “mYpRoJeCt”, it
 > will be created successfully."

Yeah in case of PostgreSQL, yes it will be two different resources. I think you have point here about not ignoring the PostgreSQL case. After rethinking on this, let's configure the resource name properly in conf with same case-sensitive as keystone handle with your configured backend.'}, {'account_id': 17887, 'date': '2019-07-18 14:12:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> > as to "because you cannot create two users with 'user' and 'User'
 > > name in keystone.", the doc says that
 > > "PostgreSQL¶
 > > PostgreSQL is case-sensitive by default, so if a project by the
 > > name of “myproject” is created with the existing “mYpRoJeCt”, it
 > > will be created successfully."
 > 
 > Yeah in case of PostgreSQL, yes it will be two different resources.
 > I think you have point here about not ignoring the PostgreSQL case.
 > After rethinking on this, let's configure the resource name
 > properly in conf with same case-sensitive as keystone handle with
 > your configured backend.

The docs also state below that 
LDAP By default, LDAP DNs are case-insensitive, so the example with users under MySQL will apply here as well.

So should we have a tempest.conf for keystone case-sensitive-backend and a util method to get_keystone_name that lower when false?

https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/case-insensitive.html'}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2019-07-19 01:51:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

Yes, some backends are case-insensitive. And, I just think "configure the resource name properly in conf" is not a tough task, not worthing adding a config item for it:)'}, {'account_id': 17887, 'date': '2019-07-19 15:34:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> Yes, some backends are case-insensitive. And, I just think
 > "configure the resource name properly in conf" is not a tough task,
 > not worthing adding a config item for it:)

Our issue is we are using a corporate LDAP instance and the user name is either upper case or lower case depending on the admin that enter it.  To fix that would be difficult at the LDAP level. 

Please let me know if you want to talk more about this or if this is a bug that will not be addressed.

Thank you all for your time.'}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2019-07-22 00:55:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

"To fix that would be difficult at the LDAP level", I can understand this, and why it's difficult to fetch the name from LDAP and fill it in the tempest.conf?
I will not strongly object to this change, so let's see what other opinions are:)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-22 06:15:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> > Yes, some backends are case-insensitive. And, I just think
 > > "configure the resource name properly in conf" is not a tough
 > task,
 > > not worthing adding a config item for it:)
 > 
 > Our issue is we are using a corporate LDAP instance and the user
 > name is either upper case or lower case depending on the admin that
 > enter it.  To fix that would be difficult at the LDAP level.
 > 
 > Please let me know if you want to talk more about this or if this
 > is a bug that will not be addressed.
 > 
 > Thank you all for your time.

I might not be getting the complete problem here. But keystone preserves the case-sensitive things. I mean if LDAP is backend then, user 'UserName' will be stored as 'UserName' not 'username' right? and keystone will error if anyone try to create user with 'username'.

for PostgreSQL, 'UserName' and 'username' both can exist at the same time.

overall keystone does not change the case from the original user creation request. so configuring the same user name(lower or upper case) whatever present in keystone(return by keystone API) in tempest.conf solve the problem. 

test if verifying what keystone return and what tester enter in conf.'}, {'account_id': 17887, 'date': '2019-07-23 02:12:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> > > Yes, some backends are case-insensitive. And, I just think
 > > > "configure the resource name properly in conf" is not a tough
 > > task,
 > > > not worthing adding a config item for it:)
 > >
 > > Our issue is we are using a corporate LDAP instance and the user
 > > name is either upper case or lower case depending on the admin
 > that
 > > enter it.  To fix that would be difficult at the LDAP level.
 > >
 > > Please let me know if you want to talk more about this or if this
 > > is a bug that will not be addressed.
 > >
 > > Thank you all for your time.
 > 
 > I might not be getting the complete problem here. But keystone
 > preserves the case-sensitive things. I mean if LDAP is backend
 > then, user 'UserName' will be stored as 'UserName' not 'username'
 > right? and keystone will error if anyone try to create user with
 > 'username'.
 > 
 > for PostgreSQL, 'UserName' and 'username' both can exist at the
 > same time.
 > 
 > overall keystone does not change the case from the original user
 > creation request. so configuring the same user name(lower or upper
 > case) whatever present in keystone(return by keystone API) in
 > tempest.conf solve the problem.
 > 
 > test if verifying what keystone return and what tester enter in
 > conf.

I place a comment in the bug since I gave 3 examples of our token call with the ldap backend. see https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1836618 and let me know what you think'}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2019-07-23 08:47:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

As gmann ever asked, "Is account.yaml manually updated or it is auto-generated from tempest tool?" I can understand there will be problem if username in account.yaml is not identical with that in LDAP, but I'm curious why it's difficult to make them identical?'}, {'account_id': 17887, 'date': '2019-07-23 11:51:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> As gmann ever asked, "Is account.yaml manually updated or it is
 > auto-generated from tempest tool?" I can understand there will be
 > problem if username in account.yaml is not identical with that in
 > LDAP, but I'm curious why it's difficult to make them identical?
The accounts.yaml is generated from user input you cannot auto generate from LDAP since the user are immutable. 

We do not validate the Cred’s at the time that we do the account generate we could validate the creds and adjust he name to the backend at that time.  

Thank you for the discussion,  patients and idea. We will look into that. We do have one more idea that I will have Maanasa submit if you think that idea is to high cost please vote it down and we will abandon this patch-set and we will address it in the accounts.yaml tool. FY we cannot use Tempest account-generate since it creates user and LDAP is an immutable user source. We will be submitting a spec for the immutable accounts.yaml tool that we created. 

Once again thank you for your time.'}, {'account_id': 17887, 'date': '2019-07-24 02:00:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)

What about this direction?'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-24 17:48:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 17887, 'date': '2019-07-25 03:13:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Sorry, I did something wrong with the version control and those changes have not got reflected previously.'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-26 14:21:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-26 17:53:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-27 10:58:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > What about this direction?

Thanks but this loses the validation. Keystone should keep the consistency in storing the case-sensitivity in same backend. I commented on bug and added keystone in that. 

Let's get clear pic from keystone team whether it is keystone bug or tempest mis-configuration. 

-1 till then."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-27 11:24:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

let's get input from keystone team on this."}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-29 14:03:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 30690, 'date': '2019-07-29 19:05:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-07-30 00:46:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

(2 comments)

I think it would be easier to just keep the usernames consistent in the config, but regardless of that I think it's fine to handle this on tempest's side, rather than on keystone's."}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2019-07-30 04:22:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

My only concern is that the case-sensitive backend case such as PostgreSQL. If we do lower() to compare request and response username values, we might miss a (probably rare) case of bugs which should raise an error. However, I don't want to introduce a new config option to Tempest such as `case-sensitive-backend` easily because it makes Tempest more complicated.


> LDAP By default, LDAP DNs are case-insensitive, so the example with users under MySQL will apply here as well.
> So should we have a tempest.conf for keystone case-sensitive-backend and a util method to get_keystone_name that lower when false?

So, how about using `immutable_user_source` here? Because I think most of the `immutable_user_source`==True case is LDAP. Is this a silly idea?


My '-1' reason is for a bit complicated condition to lower() or not."}, {'account_id': 17887, 'date': '2019-07-31 01:43:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

Since these changes are not straight forward for all concerned we will update of accounts.yaml internal build process to get our config correct according to the back end name even if the user end in the wrong case.  Thanks for the input I will have manes abandon this commit.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-31 02:44:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-31 02:45:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > My only concern is that the case-sensitive backend case such as
 > PostgreSQL. If we do lower() to compare request and response
 > username values, we might miss a (probably rare) case of bugs which
 > should raise an error. However, I don't want to introduce a new
 > config option to Tempest such as `case-sensitive-backend` easily
 > because it makes Tempest more complicated.
 > 
 > 
 > > LDAP By default, LDAP DNs are case-insensitive, so the example
 > with users under MySQL will apply here as well.
 > > So should we have a tempest.conf for keystone case-sensitive-backend
 > and a util method to get_keystone_name that lower when false?
 > 
 > So, how about using `immutable_user_source` here? Because I think
 > most of the `immutable_user_source`==True case is LDAP. Is this a
 > silly idea?
 > 
 > 
 > My '-1' reason is for a bit complicated condition to lower() or
 > not.

I think we do not need to test the backend behaviour in Tempest. we will go with what keystone behaves with their APIs. if any error on backend side on case-sensitive changes then it should be cathed by unit test on the backend side."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-31 02:47:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I think we can handle this in Tempest. As keystone will return the username as per how it was stored in backend than how it was requested, i can understand it will not easy to configure the username correctly everytime with case-sensitive on tempest.conf 

I am ok with checking the both as lower case without any condition.'}, {'account_id': 17887, 'date': '2019-07-31 21:02:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Fix Upstream test cases to be case insensitive

In any domain, due to case sensitivity, if a username
for the project and the username in tempest.conf or
accounts.yaml are not identical, then the test cases
are failing.

So, added .lower() method to change the username strings
to be case insensitive.

Closes-Bug: #1836618

Change-Id: Id7d079c881bbfae972d65ef6049f78da7f25fc1d

commit_message:
Fixes packages for arm64 bootloader

Should install "grub2-efi-aa64 grub2-efi-aa64-modules" instead of
"grub2-efi grub2-efi-modules" for arm64

Change-Id: Iee3191b0944b3b862890d166a9d36bd592fe8f7e
Closes-bug: #1839816

commit_message:
Fit the StopIteration for py37

In Train we will switch to use py37 for tests.
There is a breaking change between Python 3.6 and 3.7
that is making it an error to raise a StopIteration exception
from a function or generator(https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0479/).
So we need to fix it in code.

Change-Id: I003be4193944bc4176768c488f2f71b58fcbd58d
Closes-Bug: #1837856
Story: #2005924
Task: #34258

commit_message:
Refactor the unplugging of the VIP

This aims to make unplugging the vip based on the amphora instead
the LB for the LB delete flows.

Change-Id: Ia034ee51f8dfef7763c7ee06f11a25c7972a024b

commit_message:
